verse.text: [note]1[/note]Paul, a [note]2[/note]slave of [note]3[/note]Christ [note]4[/note]Jesus, a [note]5[/note]called [note]6[/note]apostle, [note]7[/note]separated [note]8[/note]unto the [note]9[/note]gospel of God,
verse.note: Formerly Saul, who persecuted the believers and devastated the church ([link]Acts 7:58-8:1a[/link]; [link]8:3[/link]; [link]9:1[/link]). After he was saved, when he went forth to preach the gospel, his name was changed to Paul ([link]Acts 13:9[/link]).

A slave, according to ancient custom and law, was one who was purchased by his master and over whom his master had absolute rights, even to the extent of terminating his life. Paul was such a slave of Christ. Verbs formed from this word are used several times throughout this book. One is translated [i]serve as a slave[/i] in [link]6:6[/link] and [i]serve[/i] in [link]7:6[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]9:12[/link]; [link]12:11[/link]; [link]14:18[/link]; and [link]16:18[/link]. Another is translated [i]enslaved[/i] in [link]6:18[/link], [link]22[/link]. The noun [i]slavery,[/i] from the same root as [i]slave,[/i] is used in [link]8:15[/link], [link]21[/link].[br][br]Paul's use of this term indicates that he was not a self-appointed apostle or one hired by the Lord; rather, he was one purchased to serve God and minister to His people, not in the natural life but in the regenerated life (see [link]Exo. 12:44[/link]; [link]21:6[/link]; note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link]; note [link]14[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 25[/link]; and note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 6[/link]).

[i]Christ,[/i] equal to [i]Messiah[/i] in Hebrew, means [i]the anointed One[/i] ([link]John 1:41[/link]; [link]Dan. 9:26[/link]). This book explains how the individual Christ revealed in the four Gospels could become the corporate Christ revealed in Acts, collectively composed of Himself with all the believers. By means of the facts in the Scriptures and the experience in the Holy Spirit, Paul shows us that God's New Testament economy is to make sinners sons of God and members of Christ to constitute the Body of Christ to express Him. This book offers a full definition of this, God's goal, unfolding a general sketch and details of both the Christian life and the church life.[br][br]This book may be divided into eight sections: introduction, condemnation, justification, sanctification, glorification, selection, transformation, and conclusion. In these eight sections three major structures can be seen: salvation ([link]1:1-5:11[/link]; [link]9:1-11:36[/link]), life ([link]5:12-8:39[/link]), and building ([link]12:1-16:27[/link]).
[i]Jesus,[/i] equal to [i]Joshua[/i] in Hebrew, means [i]the salvation of Jehovah,[/i] or [i]Jehovah the Savior[/i] ([link]Matt. 1:21[/link]; [link]Num. 13:16[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:8[/link]).
[i]Called[/i] includes the thought of being appointed (cf. [link]1 Cor. 12:28[/link]).
I.e., a sent one (see note [link]1[sup]3[/sup], par. 2, in 1 Cor. 9[/link]).
Being separated includes being chosen ([link]Acts 9:15[/link]), being appointed ([link]1 Tim. 2:7[/link]), and being sent ([link]Acts 13:2-4[/link]).
Or, for the gospel; including the proclamation ([link]1 Tim. 2:7[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:11[/link]) and the defense and confirmation ([link]Phil. 1:7[/link]) of the gospel.

Lit., glad tidings, good news ([link]vv. 9[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]2:16[/link]; [link]10:16[/link]; [link]11:28[/link]; [link]15:16[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]16:25[/link]). The gospel of God, as the subject of this book, concerns Christ as the Spirit living within the believers after His resurrection. This is higher and more subjective than what was presented in the Gospels, which concern Christ only in the flesh as He lived among His disciples after His incarnation but before His death and resurrection. This book, however, reveals that Christ has resurrected and has become the life-giving Spirit ([link]8:9-10[/link]). He is no longer merely the Christ outside the believers, but He is now the Christ within them. Hence, the gospel in this book is the gospel of the One who is now indwelling His believers as their subjective Savior.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Which He promised [note]2[/note]beforehand through His prophets in the [note]3[/note]holy Scriptures,
verse.note: [link]Verses 2-6[/link] may be considered a parenthetical word explaining the gospel of God.

The gospel of God was not something added along the way by accident; it was planned and prepared by God in eternity past and promised by God through His prophets in many ways ([link]Gen. 3:15[/link]; [link]22:18[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:9[/link]; [link]Titus 1:2[/link]).

The Greek words [i]hagios, hagiosune, hagiazo,[/i] and [i]hagiasmos,[/i] used in this book, are of the same root, which fundamentally means [i]separated, set apart. Hagios[/i] is translated [i]holy[/i] in [link]v. 2[/link]; [link]5:5[/link]; [link]7:12[/link]; [link]9:1[/link]; [link]11:16[/link]; [link]12:1[/link]; [link]14:17[/link]; [link]15:13[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]16:16[/link], and [i]saints[/i] in [link]v. 7[/link]; [link]8:27[/link]; [link]12:13[/link]; [link]15:25[/link], [link]26[/link], [link]31[/link]; [link]16:15[/link]. [i]Hagiosune[/i] is translated [i]holiness[/i] in [link]v. 4[/link]. [i]Hagiazo[/i] is a verb used as a participle and is translated [i]sanctified[/i] in [link]15:16[/link]. [i]Hagiasmos[/i] is translated [i]sanctification[/i] in [link]6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]. Hence, to be holy is to be separated, set apart (to God). The saints are the separated ones, the ones set apart (to God). Holiness is the nature and quality of being holy. Sanctification (to God) is the practical effect, the character in activity, and the consummate state produced by being sanctified.

verse.text: Concerning [note]1[/note]His Son, who [note]2[/note]came [note]3[/note]out of the [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]seed of David according to the [note]5[/note]flesh,
verse.note: The gospel of God concerns the Son of God, Jesus Christ our Lord. This wonderful person has two natures — the divine nature ([link]v. 4[/link]) and the human nature ([link]v. 3[/link]), divinity and humanity.
Lit., became.

[i]Out of,[/i] a literal translation of the Greek [i]ek,[/i] is used here and again in the next verse, referring to the two sources of Christ's being: one, the seed of David, the other, the resurrection of the dead.
[i]The seed of David[/i] implies Christ's human nature. By incarnation, the first step of Christ's process, God was brought into humanity.

In the Bible [i]flesh[/i] is not a positive word. Nevertheless, the Bible declares that the Word became flesh ([link]John 1:14[/link]). The gospel of God concerns God who became flesh; according to the flesh He became the seed of a man (see note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]).

verse.text: Who was [note]1[/note]designated the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of God in [note]3[/note]power according to the [note]4[/note]Spirit of [note]5[/note]holiness [note]6[/note]out of the resurrection of the dead, Jesus Christ our Lord;
verse.note: Or, marked out. Before His incarnation Christ, the divine One, already was the Son of God ([link]John 1:18[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link]). By incarnation He put on an element, the human flesh, which had nothing to do with divinity; that part of Him needed to be sanctified and uplifted by passing through death and resurrection. By resurrection His human nature was sanctified, uplifted, and transformed. Hence, by resurrection He was designated the Son of God with His humanity ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:5[/link]). His resurrection was His designation. Now, as the Son of God, He possesses humanity as well as divinity. By incarnation He brought God into man; by resurrection He brought man into God, that is, He brought His humanity into the divine sonship. In this way the only begotten Son of God was made the firstborn Son of God, possessing both divinity and humanity. God is using such a Christ, the firstborn Son, who possesses both divinity and humanity, as the producer and as the prototype, the model, to produce His many sons ([link]8:29-30[/link]) — we who have believed in and received His Son. We too will be designated and revealed as the sons of God, as He was in the glory of His resurrection ([link]8:19[/link], [link]21[/link]), and with Him we will express God.

This book tells us that God's full salvation is to make sinners ([link]3:23[/link]), even His enemies ([link]5:10[/link]), the sons of God ([link]8:14[/link]). Through resurrection God designated Christ, who became flesh to be the seed of David, as His Son, that His Son, who is the mingling of divinity and humanity, might be the base and pattern for His making sinners His many sons. It is in the resurrection of His Son, i.e., in the resurrected Son, that God is producing many sons ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) as the many brothers of the Firstborn ([link]8:29[/link]), who was resurrected from the dead, and as the members of His Firstborn to constitute the Body of His Firstborn ([link]12:5[/link]), which is His fullness ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]), His corporate expression.
The reality of the power of Christ's resurrection is the Spirit (see notes in [link]Eph. 1:19-22[/link] and note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in Phil. 3[/link]).

The Spirit of holiness here is in contrast to the flesh in [link]v. 3[/link]. As the flesh in [link]v. 3[/link] refers to the human nature of Christ in the flesh, so the Spirit in this verse does not refer to the person of the Holy Spirit of God but to the divine essence of Christ. This divine essence of Christ, being God the Spirit Himself ([link]John 4:24[/link]), the divinity of Christ, is of holiness, full of the nature and quality of being holy.
See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup][/link].

See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup][/link]. [i]Out of[/i] here should be linked to [i]designated[/i] in the first part of this verse. Christ was designated the Son of God out of the resurrection of the dead.

verse.text: Through whom we have received [note]1[/note]grace and [note]2[/note]apostleship unto the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]obedience of [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith among all the Gentiles [note]5[/note]on behalf of His name,
verse.note: Grace is God in Christ as life and the life supply (see note [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in John 1[/link]). It affords the apostles salvation and life and becomes the capacity and supply for their apostleship ([link]1 Cor. 15:9-10[/link]).
I.e., sending forth, or mission.

God's unique commandment in this age, the age of grace, is that man should believe into His Son, the Lord Jesus. Whoever believes into Him will be saved; whoever does not believe has been condemned already, because he has not believed into Him ([link]John 3:18[/link]). The Holy Spirit convicts the world of the sin of not believing into the Lord ([link]John 16:8-9[/link]), of not obeying God's unique commandment. When we believe into the Lord, we have the obedience of faith, and the result is grace and peace ([link]v. 7[/link]).

In the New Testament the complete gospel according to God's New Testament revelation is the content of the faith, with the two natures of Christ, who is both God and man, and the redemptive work accomplished through His death and resurrection as its center (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in 1 Tim. 1[/link]). To obey this faith is to turn from all pagan religions and philosophies unto this faith, believing and receiving it.
Christ's name denotes His person, Himself. [i]On behalf of His name[/i] denotes for Him, for His sake, for His interests.

verse.text: Among whom you also are the [note]1[/note]called ones of Jesus Christ;
verse.note: God calls us for the purpose of bringing us into Christ that we may belong to Him. All the fullness of God is in Christ ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]; [link]1:19[/link]). When we are brought into Him and belong to Him, we partake of all the fullness of God. Of His fullness we have received all that is of God, even grace upon grace ([link]John 1:16[/link]). This matter is covered in detail in the first eight chapters of this book (cf. [link]8:9[/link]).

verse.text: To all who are in Rome, beloved of God, the [xref]a[/xref]called [note]1[/note]saints: [note]2[/note]Grace to you and [xref]b[/xref]peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup][/link].

Grace is God in Christ as our enjoyment (see [link]John 1:14[/link], [link]16-17[/link]; notes [link book="Rom." chapter="5"]2[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 5[/link]); it is the source. Peace is the result of our enjoyment of God in Christ ([link]John 16:33[/link]); it is the issue.

verse.text: First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all because your [xref]a[/xref]faith is proclaimed throughout the whole world.
For God is my witness, whom I [note]1[/note]serve in my [note]2[/note]spirit in the gospel of His Son, how unceasingly I make mention of you always in my prayers,
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]serve in worship;[/i] it is used in [link]Matt. 4:10[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:3[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:3[/link]; and [link]Luke 2:37[/link]. Paul considered his preaching of the gospel a worship and service to God, not merely a work.

Not the Spirit of God but Paul's regenerated spirit. The spirit is different from the heart, soul, mind, emotion, will, or natural life. Christ and the Spirit are with the believers in their regenerated human spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:16[/link]). In this book Paul stressed that whatever we are ([link]2:29[/link]; [link]8:5-6[/link], [link]9[/link]), whatever we have ([link]8:10[/link], [link]16[/link]), and whatever we do toward God ([link]v. 9[/link]; [link]7:6[/link]; [link]8:4[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]12:11[/link]) must be in this spirit. Paul served God in his regenerated spirit by the indwelling Christ, the life-giving Spirit, not in his soul by the power and ability of the soul. This is the first important item in his preaching of the gospel.

verse.text: Beseeching if by any means now at last I may be prospered in the will of God to come to you.
For I long to see you that I may impart to you some spiritual gift so that you may be [xref]a[/xref]established;
That is, that I with [i]you[/i] may be [note]1[/note]encouraged among you through the faith which is in one another, both yours and mine.
verse.note: Or, comforted.

verse.text: And I do not want you to be ignorant, brothers, that often I [xref]a[/xref]purposed to come to you (yet was hindered until the present), that I might have some fruit among you also, even as among the rest of the Gentiles.
I am debtor both to Greeks and to [note]1[/note]barbarians, both to wise and to foolish;
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 14[/link].

verse.text: So, for my part, I am ready to announce the gospel to you also who are in Rome.
For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the [note]1[/note]power of God unto [note]2[/note]salvation to everyone who believes, both to Jew first and to Greek.
verse.note: Denoting a powerful force that can break through any obstacle. This power is the resurrected Christ Himself, who is the life-giving Spirit, and it is unto salvation to everyone who believes.

To save the believing ones not only from God's condemnation and from eternal perdition but also from their natural life and their self, that they may be sanctified, transformed, and built up with others as the one Body of Christ to be His fullness and expression ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]).

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteousness of God is revealed in it [note]2[/note]out of faith to faith, as it is written, [xref]b[/xref]"But the righteous shall [note]3[/note]have life and live by [note]4[/note]faith."
verse.note: In [link]John 3:16[/link] God's love is the source and motive of God's salvation. In [link]Eph. 2:5[/link], [link]8[/link] God's grace is the means of God's salvation. Here God's righteousness is the power of God's salvation. God's righteousness, which is solid and steadfast, is the foundation of His throne ([link]Psa. 89:14[/link]) and the base on which His kingdom is built ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]). Legally, both love and grace can fluctuate, but righteousness cannot. It is even more so with God's righteousness. It is God's righteousness, not ours, that is revealed in the gospel of God. Hence, the gospel is the power of God unto salvation to everyone who believes.

[i]Out of faith[/i] indicates that faith is the source and the foundation of the revelation of God's righteousness; [i]to faith[/i] indicates that faith is the receiver and container that receives and retains God's righteousness. If we have this faith, God's righteousness will be made visible to us and will be laid hold of by us.

The righteousness of God justifies us that we may have God's life ([link]5:18[/link]) and live by it. In this way this life will sanctify and transform us thoroughly. This book covers mainly our being justified ([link]1:1-5:11[/link]; [link]9:1-11:36[/link]), our having life ([link]5:12-8:39[/link]), and our living properly by this life ([link]12:1-16:27[/link]). Since this verse also stresses these three points, it may be considered an abstract of the entire book.
See note [link]20[sup]5[/sup] in Gal. 2[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]wrath of God is revealed from heaven [note]3[/note]upon all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who [note]4[/note]hold down [note]5[/note]the truth in unrighteousness,
verse.note: This book begins with man's fall (in contrast to Ephesians, which begins with God's selection and predestination in eternity past); continues through Christ's redemption, God's justification, sanctification, transformation, conformation, and glorification; and, finally, touches the mystery of God in eternity past ([link]16:25[/link]).

In the preceding verse the righteousness of God is revealed in the gospel to faith; here, the wrath of God is revealed from heaven upon all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men. This shows a contrast between the revelation of God's righteousness and the revelation of God's wrath. Originally, the wrath of God was revealed from heaven upon all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men. However, since the gospel of God has come, the scene has changed. Now the righteousness of God is revealed in the gospel to our faith.
Implying against, or in opposition to.
To hold down means to suppress. From the beginning mankind did not respect the truth of God but suppressed it unrighteously.

The truth here refers to the first true thing, the first reality, concerning man and God in the universe. This reality is the sure fact that God and His existence are proved by the creation, and it is the definite fact that men, being without excuse, can know God by the creation. This great reality, this great truth, should cause men to know God and thereby to glorify Him and thank Him ([link]v. 21[/link]). However, instead of dealing properly with this reality, this truth, according to righteousness, in which God delights, men held down the truth in unrighteousness, which God hates, and did not approve of knowing God ([link]v. 28[/link]). Therefore, they despised and rejected God, changing the glory of God into idols ([link]vv. 21-23[/link]) and casting off self-restraint to fall without limit ([link]vv. 24-32[/link]), so that they were given up, abandoned, by God ([link]vv. 24[/link], [link]26[/link], [link]28[/link]).

verse.text: Because that which is known of God is manifest [note]1[/note]within them, for God manifested [i]it[/i] to them.
verse.note: Or, among.

verse.text: For the invisible things of Him, both His eternal power and [note]1[/note]divine characteristics, have been clearly seen since the creation of the world, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]being perceived by the things made, so that they would be without excuse;
verse.note: Gk. [i]theiotes,[/i] denoting God's attributes, which are the special features, the characteristics, as the outward manifestations of God's nature or substance. It is different from [i]theotes[/i] in [link]Col. 2:9[/link], which denotes God's Godhead and person. The characteristics of God's nature can be verified through the created things; however, the created things cannot manifest God's Godhead and person. Only the living person of Jesus Christ, the Word who is God and who declares God ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]18[/link]), can express God's Godhead and person, that is, the very God, God Himself. Here, in this chapter, the apostle Paul speaks of the created things verifying God's existence, but what is verified are only the attributes and characteristics of God. In [link]Col. 2:9[/link] he speaks of Christ as the embodiment of God, and what is expressed is the Godhead and God's person, that is, God Himself.

Man can perceive the invisible things of God by observing the visible things created by Him. Both the eternal power of God and the divine characteristics that express God's intrinsic nature are manifested in God's creation. For example, the abundance of light in the universe shows that light is a divine characteristic, a divine attribute of the divine nature ([link]James 1:17[/link]). The same is true of beauty and life.

verse.text: Because though [note]1[/note]they knew God, they did not glorify [i]Him[/i] as God or thank [i]Him,[/i] but [i]rather[/i] became [note]2[/note]vain in their reasonings, and their heart, lacking understanding, was darkened.
verse.note: In this chapter Paul's presentation of God's creation and man's step-by-step fall is undoubtedly based on the historical facts as recorded in [link]Gen. 1-19[/link] and in subsequent books of the Old Testament. First, [link]vv. 19-20[/link] speak concerning God's creation; then [link]vv. 21-25[/link] cover the fall of Adam and progress through the age of the flood to the worshipping of idols at Babel. [link]Verses 26-27[/link] progress further, from Babel to the shameful lusts of Sodom, and [link]vv. 28-32[/link] go on from Sodom to every kind of wickedness in the Old Testament time.
Vain reasonings are the basic element in the daily life of fallen mankind. See note [link]17[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 4[/link].

verse.text: Professing to be wise, they became fools
And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]changed the glory of the incorruptible God into the likeness of an image of corruptible man and of birds and four-footed animals and reptiles.
verse.note: To change the glory of God into anything else is to forsake Him and to make an idol.

verse.text: Therefore God [note]1[/note]gave them up in the lusts of their hearts to uncleanness, so that they dishonor their bodies among themselves,
verse.note: The same expression is used also in [link]vv. 26[/link] and [link]28[/link]. The result of man's giving up God is man's being given up by Him. Those who give up God force God to give them up. According to this chapter God gives people up to three things: uncleanness ([link]v. 24[/link]), passions of dishonor ([link]v. 26[/link]), and a disapproved mind ([link]v. 28[/link]). The consequence of such a giving up is fornication ([link]vv. 24[/link], [link]26-27[/link]), which violates a governing and controlling principle and brings in confusion. Every kind of evil issues from this fornication ([link]vv. 29-32[/link]).

verse.text: Who exchanged the [note]1[/note]truth of God for the lie, and worshipped and served the creation rather than the Creator, who is [xref]a[/xref]blessed forever. Amen.
verse.note: The truth of God is the reality of God. God is true and real. What He is, is a reality. But the idols are false. Whatever they are is a lie.

verse.text: Therefore God gave them up to passions of dishonor; for their females exchanged the natural use for that which is contrary to nature;

And likewise also the males, leaving the natural use of the female, burned in their craving toward one another, males with males committing unseemliness and fully receiving in themselves the retribution of their error which was due.
And even as they did not approve of holding God in [i]their[/i] full knowledge, God gave them up to a disapproved mind, to do the things which are not fitting,
Being filled with all unrighteousness, wickedness, covetousness, malice; full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, malignity;
Whisperers, slanderers, hateful to God, insolent, arrogant, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents,
Senseless, faithless, affectionless, merciless;

Who, though fully knowing the [note]1[/note]righteous judgment of God, that those who practice such things are worthy of death, not only do them, but also have fellow delight in those who practice [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: Or, righteous requirement, as in [link]8:4[/link]; that is, the requirement of God's righteous will. Hence, this phrase also refers to the judgment that is out of God's will ([link]Rev. 15:4[/link]), or to statutes with judgments, that is, ordinances ([link]2:26[/link]; [link]Luke 1:6[/link]), or to the righteous act that meets God's requirement ([link]5:18[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore you are without excuse, O every man who [note]1[/note]judges, for in what you judge another you condemn yourself; for you who judge practice the same things.
verse.note: Meaning [i]to pass judgment, to criticize.[/i] So in subsequent verses.

verse.text: But we know that the [note]1[/note]judgment of God is according to [note]2[/note]truth upon those who practice such things.
verse.note: Referring to God's eternal judgment, which will be carried out mainly at the great white throne, as revealed in [link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]. See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 14[/link].

[i]Truth[/i] here and in [link]vv. 8[/link], [link]20[/link] denotes the reality revealed through the creation and through the Bible concerning God, the universe, man, the relationship between man and God, the relationships among men, and man's obligation to God. It also refers to the actual situation and condition of man, and it may be the terms of God's judgment upon man, as indicated in [link]vv. 6-15[/link]. According to these terms God will execute His judgment righteously.

verse.text: And do you consider this, O man, who judge those who practice such things and do the same [i]yourself,[/i] that you will escape the [note]1[/note]judgment of God?
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup][/link]. So in [link]vv. 5[/link], [link]16[/link].

verse.text: Or do you despise the riches of His kindness and forbearance and long-suffering, not knowing that God's kindness is leading you to repentance?
But, according to your hardness and [i]your[/i] unrepentant heart, you are storing up for yourself wrath in the day of wrath and revelation of the [xref]a[/xref]righteous judgment of God,
Who will render to each according to his works:
[note]1[/note]To those who by endurance in good work seek glory and honor and incorruptibility, life eternal;
verse.note: [link]Verses 7-10[/link] give the basic terms of God's eternal judgment.

verse.text: But to those who are selfishly contentious and disobedient to the [note]1[/note]truth and obey unrighteousness, wrath and fury.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Tribulation and anguish upon every soul of man who commits evil, both of Jew first and of Greek;
But glory and honor and peace to everyone who works good, both to Jew first and to Greek.
For there is no respect of persons with God.
For as many as have sinned without the law shall also perish without the law; and as many as have sinned [note]1[/note]under the law shall be judged by the law
verse.note: Lit., in law; i.e., in the sphere of law.

verse.text: (For [i]it is[/i] not the hearers of the law [i]who[/i] are righteous before God, but the doers of the law shall be justified.
For when Gentiles, who have no law, do [note]1[/note]by nature the things of the law, these, though they have no law, are a law to themselves,
verse.note: The nature of man, as created by God, was originally good and corresponded with God and with His law. Although it was poisoned by the fall, this good nature remains within man. Hence, if anyone lives according to his nature and does by his nature the things of the law, the evil in him will be restricted.

verse.text: Who show the work of the law written in their hearts, their [note]1[/note]conscience bearing witness with [i]it[/i] and their reasonings, one with the other, accusing or even excusing [i]them[/i].)
verse.note: Man's conscience corresponds with the God-created human nature and enables man to know what God justifies and what He condemns.

verse.text: In the day when God judges the secrets of men according to my gospel [xref]a[/xref]through Jesus Christ.
[note]1[/note]But if you bear the name of Jew, and rest upon the law, and [note]2[/note]boast in God,
verse.note: In this section, which specifically deals with God's condemnation on the religious, Paul first points out the pitiful condition of the Jews, who represent the religious people. They have only the vanity of their religious rituals, letters, and knowledge; they do not have God as their reality.
In the Jewish religion God is known only outwardly and objectively, not inwardly and subjectively. This shows the vanity of human religion.

verse.text: And know the will, and [note]1[/note]approve the things that are more excellent, being instructed out of the law,
verse.note: Or, prove the things that differ.

verse.text: And have confidence that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those in darkness,
One who disciplines the foolish, a teacher of [note]1[/note]babes, having the proper form of the knowledge and truth in the law;
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]little children[/i] in [link]Eph. 4:14[/link] and [i]child[/i] in [link]Gal. 4:1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]You therefore who teach another, do you not teach yourself? You who preach not to steal, do you steal?
verse.note: That the religious people practice the same evils as the unreligious exposes the vanity of their religion. See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: You who say not to commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob [i]their[/i] temples?
You who boast in the law, do you by transgression of the law dishonor God?
For [xref]a[/xref]"the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you," even as it is written.
For circumcision profits if you practice the law; but if you are a transgressor of the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
If therefore the uncircumcision keeps the [note]1[/note]ordinances of the law, will not his uncircumcision be accounted as circumcision?
verse.note: Or, requirements.

verse.text: And the uncircumcision by nature, if he fulfills the law, will judge you who through the letter and circumcision are a transgressor of the law.
[note]1[/note]For he is [xref]a[/xref]not a Jew who is one [note]2[/note]outwardly; neither is [xref]b[/xref]circumcision that which is outward in the flesh.
verse.note: Lit., For the [i]Jew[/i] in what is manifest is not a Jew; neither is the [i]circumcision[/i] in what is manifest in the flesh circumcision.
Any religious practice, such as circumcision, that is merely an outward form is not real. See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But he is a Jew who is one inwardly; and circumcision is of the heart, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]in spirit, not [note]2[/note]in letter, whose praise is not [note]3[/note]from men, but [note]3[/note]from God.
verse.note: Lit., But the [i]Jew[/i] in what is hidden is a Jew.

I.e., based on. Whatever we are, whatever we do, and whatever we have must be in spirit. This will keep us from the vanity of religion. See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. The reality of all spiritual things depends on the Spirit of God, and the Spirit of God is in our spirit. Hence, the reality of all spiritual matters depends on our spirit, not on anything apart from our spirit. Whatever is in us is vanity unless it is in our spirit. Everything that God is to us is in our spirit.
Lit., out of.

verse.text: What then is the advantage of the Jew? Or what is the profit of the circumcision?
Much in every way. First, that they were entrusted with the oracles of God.
For what if some disbelieved? Shall their unbelief annul the faithfulness of God?

[note]1[/note]Absolutely not! But let God be true and every man a liar, as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"That You may be [note]2[/note]declared righteous in Your words and may overcome when You are judged."
verse.note: Lit., May it not happen. So throughout this Epistle.
God must first convince us of His righteousness before we can repent and believe into Him. Thus, He is declared righteous by us before we are declared righteous by Him.

verse.text: But if our unrighteousness commends the righteousness of God, what shall we say? Is the God who inflicts wrath unrighteous? I speak according to man.
Absolutely not! Otherwise how shall God judge the world?
But if the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]truthfulness of God has abounded in my lie unto His glory, why still am I also being judged as a sinner?
verse.note: In Greek the same word as for [i]truth[/i] (reality). The word here and in [link]15:8[/link] denotes genuineness, sincerity, honesty, faithfulness, and trustworthiness as one of God's virtues (see note [link]6[sup]6[/sup], item 7, in 1 John 1[/link]).

verse.text: And why not [i]say[/i] (as we are slanderously charged and as some affirm that we say), Let us do evil that good may come? whose [note]1[/note]judgment is just.
verse.note: The eternal judgment. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: What then? Are we better? Not at all! For we have previously charged both Jews and Greeks that they are all under sin,
Even as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"There is none righteous, not even one;
There is none who understands, there is none who seeks out God.
All have turned aside; together they have become useless; there is none who does [note]1[/note]good; there is not so much as one.
verse.note: Or, kindness.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Their throat is an opened grave; with their tongues they practiced deceit; [xref]b[/xref]the poison of asps is under their lips;
[xref]a[/xref]Whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness.
[xref]a[/xref]Swift are their feet to shed blood,
Destruction and misery are in their ways,
And the [note]1[/note]way of peace they have not known.
verse.note: When we were sinners, we did not know the way of peace. Now, however, we have peace toward God ([link]5:1[/link]); that is, we are at peace with God.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]There is no fear of God before their eyes."
Now we know that whatever things the law says, it speaks to those who are under the law, [note]1[/note]that every mouth may be stopped and all the world may fall under the judgment of God;
verse.note: God's purpose in giving the law was to expose man, to subdue man, and to guard or keep God's chosen ones for Christ that they may be led to Christ (see notes on [link]Gal. 3:23-24[/link]).

verse.text: Because [xref]a[/xref]out of the works of the law no flesh shall be justified before Him; for [xref]b[/xref]through the law is the clear knowledge of sin.
But now, [note]1[/note]apart from the law, the [note]2[/note]righteousness of God has been [note]3[/note]manifested, witness being borne to [i]it[/i] by the Law and the Prophets;
verse.note: God's righteousness, which is revealed in the gospel ([link]1:17[/link]), is the basis and foundation of His dispensing Himself into man in His New Testament economy. This righteousness has nothing to do with the law in His Old Testament economy (see [link]Phil. 3:9[/link] and notes there).
See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So in the next verse.

The Jews sought the righteousness of God by keeping the law. However, they did not attain to it, for out of the works of the law no flesh shall be justified before God ([link]v. 20[/link]). But now apart from the law the righteousness of God has been manifested to us through faith in Christ ([link]1:17[/link]).

verse.text: Even the righteousness of God through the [note]1[/note]faith of Jesus Christ to all those who believe, for there is no distinction;
verse.note: Or, faith in Jesus Christ. This faith refers to the faith of Jesus Christ in us, which has become the faith by which we believe in Him, as in [link]v. 26[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:16[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]3:22[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:12[/link]; and [link]Phil. 3:9[/link].[br][br]Faith has an object, and it issues from its object. This object is Jesus, who is God incarnate. When man hears Him, knows Him, appreciates Him, and treasures Him, He causes faith to be generated in man, enabling man to believe in Him. Thus, He becomes the faith in man by which man believes in Him. Hence, this faith becomes the faith in Him, and it is also the faith that belongs to Him.[br][br]In God's New Testament economy, God desires that man believe in Jesus, who is God incarnate. If man does not believe in Him, he commits the unique sin before God ([link]John 16:9[/link]). However, if man believes in Him, he is righteous to the uttermost before God, and God reckons this faith as his righteousness. At the same time, this faith brings its object, that is, this One who is God incarnate, into those who believe in Him. He is God's righteousness, and God has given Him as righteousness to those who are indwelt by Him ([link]Jer. 23:6[/link]). All this is out of, and depends on, the faith that is in Him and of Him ([link]Heb. 12:2[/link]).

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]all have sinned and fall short of the [note]1[/note]glory of God,
verse.note: God's glory is God expressed. Whenever God is expressed, His glory is seen. Man was made by God in His image that man might express Him for His glory. But man has sinned and has contradicted the holiness and righteousness of God. Instead of expressing God, man expresses sin and his sinful self. Hence, man falls short of God's glory. This falling short of God's glory and expression is sin. Sinners are not only under the requirements of God's holiness and righteousness but also under the demand of God's glory. All have offended God's holy being and have broken God's righteous law, and all are short of God's glory. Therefore, all are under God's condemnation.

verse.text: Being [note]1[/note]justified [note]2[/note]freely by His grace through the [note]3[/note]redemption which is in Christ Jesus;
verse.note: Justification is God's action whereby He approves people according to His standard of righteousness. God can do this on the basis of the redemption of Christ.

Since Christ has paid the price for our sins and in His redemption has fulfilled all God's requirements on us, God, because He is just, must justify us freely. Such justification is by the grace of God, not by our works.

To redeem is to purchase back at a cost. We originally belonged to God but became lost through sin. The requirements of God's holiness, righteousness, and glory were so great upon us that it was impossible for us to fulfill them. However, God paid the price for us through Christ, repossessing us at a tremendous cost. Christ died on the cross to redeem us ([link]Gal. 3:13[/link]; [link]Titus 2:14[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]; [link]3:18[/link]); His blood obtained eternal redemption for us ([link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]).

verse.text: Whom God [note]1[/note]set forth as a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]propitiation place through faith in His blood, for the demonstrating of His righteousness, in that in His forbearance God [note]3[/note]passed over the sins that had previously occurred,
verse.note: In the Old Testament, the expiation cover, the lid of the Ark, as a type, was hidden in the Holy of Holies; in the New Testament, Christ as the propitiation place, the reality of the expiation cover, is openly set forth before all men.

The propitiation place is typified in [link]Exo. 25:17[/link] by the sin-covering lid on the Ark. The Ark was the place where God met with people. In the Ark was the law of the Ten Commandments, which by its holy and righteous requirement exposed and condemned the sins of the people who came to contact God. However, by the lid of the Ark, with the propitiating blood sprinkled on it on the Day of Expiation, the entire situation on the sinner's side was fully covered. Therefore, upon this sin-covering lid God could meet with the people who broke His righteous law, and He could do this without, governmentally, any contradiction to His righteousness, even under the observing of the cherubim that bore His glory and overshadowed the lid of the Ark. Thus, the problem between man and God was appeased, enabling God to forgive and be merciful to man and thereby to give His grace to man. This is a prefigure of Christ as the Lamb of God taking away the sin that caused man to have a problem with God ([link]John 1:29[/link]), thus satisfying all the requirements of God's holiness, righteousness, and glory and appeasing the relationship between man and God. Hence, God could pass over the people's sins that had previously occurred. And, in order to show forth His righteousness, He had to do this. This is what this verse refers to.[br][br]The Hebrew word for the lid of the Ark is [i]kapporeth,[/i] from a root meaning [i]to cover.[/i] In the Septuagint this word is translated [i]hilasterion,[/i] which means [i]the place of propitiation[/i] (implying to forgive and to give mercy — the word rendered [i]propitious[/i] in [link]Heb. 8:12[/link] is the root of [i]hilasterion,[/i] and the word rendered [i]propitiated[/i] in [link]Luke 18:13[/link] is derived from this root). The King James Version adopts the rendering "mercy seat," referring to the place where God grants mercy to man. In [link]Heb. 9:5[/link] Paul also used [i]hilasterion[/i] for the lid of the Ark. Here, in [link]Rom. 3:25[/link], the same word, [i]hilasterion,[/i] is used to show that the lid of the Ark signifies Christ as the propitiation place set forth by God.[br][br]In addition to [i]hilasterion,[/i] two other words derived from the same Greek word as [i]hilasterion[/i] are used in the New Testament to show how Christ took away man's sin to appease the relationship between man and God. One is [i]hilaskomai[/i] ([link]Heb. 2:17[/link]), which means [i]to propitiate,[/i] that is, [i]to appease,[/i] to reconcile one by satisfying the other's demand; the other is [i]hilasmos[/i] ([link]1 John 2:2[/link]; [link]4:10[/link]), which means [i]that which propitiates,[/i] that is, a propitiatory sacrifice. Christ made propitiation for our sins ([link]Heb. 2:17[/link]); hence, He has become that which propitiates, the propitiatory sacrifice, between us and God ([link]1 John 2:2[/link]; [link]4:10[/link]), and He has also become the place, as typified by the lid of the Ark ([link]Heb. 9:5[/link]), where we enjoy propitiation before God and where God gives grace to us.

During the Old Testament time, the sins of the people were not taken away but were only covered with the blood of the animal sacrifices, which were types of Christ. God passed over these covered sins until Christ came. He was the Lamb of God who took away the sin of the world ([link]John 1:29[/link]). By His death on the cross and the shedding of His blood for redemption, He carried away all the sins that had been previously covered and passed over. In passing over their sins, God demonstrated His righteousness to the Old Testament saints.

verse.text: With a view to the demonstrating of His righteousness in the present time, so that He might be righteous and the One who [note]1[/note]justifies him who is of the [note]2[/note]faith of Jesus.
verse.note: God's justifying the believers is with a view to the demonstrating of His righteousness to those in the New Testament time who are of the faith of Jesus.
Or, faith in Jesus. See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Where then is boasting? [note]1[/note]It is excluded. Through what kind of law? That of works? No, but through the law of faith.
verse.note: Lit., It is completely shut out.

verse.text: For we account that [xref]a[/xref]a man is justified by faith apart from the works of the law.
Or is He the God of the Jews only? Is He not of the Gentiles also? Yes, of the Gentiles also,
If indeed God is one, who will justify the circumcision [note]1[/note]out of faith and the [xref]a[/xref]uncircumcision [note]1[/note]through faith.
verse.note: Faith is the source out of which the circumcision, who already have the position as God's people, may be justified by God; hence, their justification is out of faith. But as to the uncircumcision, who are positionally far away and are not God's people, faith is the way for them to reach the position where they can be justified by God; hence, their justification is through faith.

verse.text: Do we then make the law of no effect through faith? Absolutely not! Rather, we establish the law.
[note]1[/note]What then shall we say that Abraham our [note]2[/note]forefather according to the flesh has found?
verse.note: After dealing in [link]ch. 3[/link] with the objective, positional justification accomplished by the death of Christ, Paul in this chapter shows the subjective, dispositional justification carried out by the resurrection of Christ. He uses Abraham as the example to show that adequate, living justification is God's deeper work in calling fallen people out of everything other than God and bringing them back to Himself, so that they place their full trust in Him rather than in themselves. In [link]Gen. 15[/link] Abraham's being justified by God was not related to sin; rather, it was for the gaining of a seed to produce a kingdom that will inherit the world ([link]v. 13[/link]). Likewise, this chapter indicates that justification is not merely for man to be delivered out of God's condemnation, but even more for God to gain many sons ([link]8:29-30[/link]) to constitute the one Body of Christ ([link]ch. 12[/link]) as the kingdom of God ([link]14:17[/link]) for the fulfillment of His purpose. The objective, positional justification covered in [link]ch. 3[/link] is related to redemption, through which man may be reconciled to God; the subjective, dispositional justification covered in [link]ch. 4[/link] is related to life, through which men may become heirs for the fulfillment of God's purpose. This requires that man's flesh and his natural ability be cut off, circumcised.
Abraham is the forefather of all believers, of both the uncircumcision who have the same faith and the circumcision who walk in the steps of the same faith.

verse.text: For if Abraham was justified out of [note]1[/note]works, he has something to boast in, but not before God.
verse.note: This refers to Abraham's doing something for God by himself, as seen in his attempts to have God accept the fruit of his efforts (first Lot, then Eliezer, then Ishmael, who was born through Hagar) as God's promised seed. The result of Abraham's being justified, however, was that he eventually stopped his own work for God. This was signified by circumcision ([link]v. 11[/link]), which is the cutting off of the flesh. Hence, circumcision became God's constant reminder to Abraham to stop his own doing and live by faith in God. Justification has nothing to do with the works and accomplishments of the flesh.

verse.text: For what does the Scripture say? [xref]a[/xref]"And Abraham [note]1[/note]believed God, and it was accounted to him as righteousness."
verse.note: Believing God was Abraham's spontaneous reaction to God's repeated appearing to him. God appeared to Abraham a number of times ([link]Gen. 12:1-3[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]13:14-17[/link]; [link]15:1-7[/link]; [link]ch. 18[/link]; [link]Acts 7:2[/link]), each time transfusing something of His glory, something of Himself, into Abraham. Hence, Abraham's believing was actually the springing up within him of the very element that God had transfused into him. God's reaction to Abraham's believing was to justify him, that is, to account him righteous. This accounting was not out of works but was based on his believing God.

verse.text: Now to the [note]1[/note]one who [xref]a[/xref]works, his [note]2[/note]wages are not accounted according to grace, but according to what is due.
verse.note: The natural man always works for God in order to receive compensation (wages). With the natural man there is no grace, faith, or enjoyment (see [link]Exo. 12:45[/link]).

God's justification is not a reward (wages) for our good works (labor); it is grace freely given to us through Christ's redemption. If God's justification were based on our good works, or if it required our good works, then it would be the wages we earn for our good works; that is, it would be something owed to us, not something freely given by God. Since God's justification is reckoned according to His grace, it is no longer out of works; otherwise, grace is no longer grace ([link]11:6[/link]). Our works can by no means replace God's grace; God's grace must be absolute.

verse.text: But to the one who does not work, but believes on Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is accounted as righteousness.
Even as David also speaks blessing on the man to whom God accounts righteousness apart from works:
[xref]a[/xref]"Blessed are they whose lawlessnesses have been forgiven, and whose sins have been covered over.
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed is the man to whom the Lord shall by no means account sin."
Is this blessing then upon the circumcision [i]only,[/i] or also upon the uncircumcision? For we say, Faith was accounted to Abraham as righteousness.
How then was it accounted? While he was in circumcision or in uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.

And he [xref]a[/xref]received the [note]1[/note]sign of circumcision, a seal of the [note]2[/note]righteousness of the faith which [i]he had[/i] while in uncircumcision, that he might be the father of all those in uncircumcision who believe, that righteousness might be accounted to them also,
verse.note: Circumcision was not the reason that Abraham was justified; rather, it was the outward sign and confirmation that God had already justified him. It denoted the cutting off of the natural strength by which he had produced Ishmael in his effort to please God. Abraham was already justified before he was circumcised, and God had already confirmed His covenant with him in [link]Gen. 15[/link]. Circumcision was to confirm the covenant from Abraham's side, to serve as a constant reminder to him that he should no longer use his natural strength and energy to please God.
See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And the father of circumcision to those who not only are of the circumcision, but who also [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which [i]he had[/i] in uncircumcision.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to walk in a regulated, definite way[/i] (see notes [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link] and [link]16[sup]4[/sup] in Phil. 3[/link]). Here it refers to walking in the steps by observing the elements of the faith. If one walks in the steps of Abraham's faith, Abraham becomes the father of circumcision to him, and this one enters into a life in which he does not trust in himself but in God, with the result that he is justified subjectively and thus becomes His genuine heir.

verse.text: For [i]it was[/i] not through the law [i]that[/i] [xref]a[/xref]the promise [i]was made[/i] to Abraham or to his seed [xref]b[/xref]that he would be the [note]1[/note]heir of the world, but through the [note]2[/note]righteousness of faith.
verse.note: Justification is for God's chosen ones to inherit the world that they may exercise God's dominion on earth ([link]Gen. 1:26[/link]).

The law was God's temporary economy (dispensation) for man in the Old Testament, since it was added temporarily because of man's transgressions ([link]Gal. 3:19[/link]); the faith is God's eternal economy (dispensation) for man in the New Testament, because it is based on God's eternal plan (cf. note [link]4[sup]4[/sup] in 1 Tim. 1[/link]). In the Old Testament God dealt with man according to the law. If, according to that dispensation of God, man would have done what God commanded in the law, he would have obtained righteousness, that is, the righteousness of the law ([link]9:31[/link]), the righteousness which is out of the law ([link]10:5[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:9[/link]). In the New Testament God deals with man according to the faith. If, according to this dispensation of God, man believes in Christ, the One in whom God has ordained that man should believe ([link]1 John 3:23[/link]), he will obtain righteousness, that is, the righteousness of faith ([link]v. 11[/link]), the righteousness which is out of faith ([link]9:30[/link]; [link]10:6[/link]). The faith, which is ordained by God in the New Testament economy and which replaces the law of the Old Testament, did not come until the New Testament time ([link]Gal. 3:23[/link], [link]25[/link]). This faith, which replaces the law, is objective to us. When according to this objective faith we believe subjectively in Christ, in whom God intended that we believe, we receive the righteousness of faith. This righteousness is the Christ whom we possess — whom we receive by our subjective believing according to the objective faith ordained by God — as God's righteousness received by us ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]).

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]if those of the law are heirs, faith has been made void and the promise has been annulled;
For [xref]a[/xref]the law works out wrath; but [xref]b[/xref]where there is no law, neither is there transgression.

Therefore [i]the inheritance is[/i] out of faith that [i]it might be[/i] according to [xref]a[/xref]grace, so that the promise may be certain to all the seed, not to that which is of the law only, but also to that which is of the faith of Abraham, who is the [note]1[/note]father of us all
verse.note: As the father of all those called by God, Abraham was the first of a new race chosen by God. We were born into the fallen Adamic race, but we have been reborn into the called-out Abrahamic race. Whoever is of faith, as Abraham was, is a member of this new race and a son of Abraham ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link]).

verse.text: (As it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"I have appointed you a father of many nations") in the sight of God whom he [note]1[/note]believed, [xref]b[/xref]who [note]2[/note]gives life to the dead and [note]3[/note]calls the things not being as being.
verse.note: Abraham believed God regarding two things: (1) the birth of Isaac, which is related to the God who "calls the things not being as being," and (2) the offering up and the gaining back of Isaac, which is related to the God who "gives life to the dead." Abraham believed such a God and applied Him to his situation. Because Abraham had such faith, he believed God's seemingly impossible word concerning the birth of Isaac, and he also immediately obeyed God's commandment to offer Isaac, believing that God would raise him from the dead ([link]Heb. 11:17-19[/link]).

This is God's great power of resurrection. This great power enables us to eliminate death and overcome all that belongs to death. Abraham experienced this great power of resurrection when he offered Isaac according to God's command.

This is God's mighty power of creation. As the creating God, He needs no material to work with; He can create something out of nothing simply by speaking: "For He spoke, and it was" ([link]Psa. 33:9[/link]).

verse.text: He beyond hope believed [note]1[/note]in hope in order that he might become the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken, [xref]a[/xref]"So shall your seed be."
verse.note: Lit., on. Abraham, as the example of one who is justified out of faith, lived by the things hoped for (see note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 11[/link]).

verse.text: And not weakening in his faith, he considered his own body as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]already dead, [xref]b[/xref]being about a hundred years old, as well as the [xref]c[/xref]deadening of Sarah's womb;
verse.note: This indicates the termination of Abraham's natural strength. This termination is related to God's justifying him subjectively.

verse.text: But with regard to the promise of God, he did not doubt in unbelief, but was empowered by faith, giving glory to God
And being fully persuaded that [xref]a[/xref]what He had promised He was able also to do.
Therefore also it was accounted to him as righteousness.
Now it was not written for his sake only that it was accounted to him,
But for ours also to whom it is to be accounted, who believe on [note]1[/note]Him who has raised Jesus our Lord from the dead,
verse.note: The faith that is accounted to us as righteousness is our believing on God, who righteously judged Christ for our sins, righteously put Him to death in our place, and righteously raised Him from the dead.

verse.text: Who was delivered for our offenses and was [note]1[/note]raised [xref]a[/xref]for our justification.
verse.note: The death of Christ has fulfilled and fully satisfied God's righteous requirements; hence, we are justified by God through His death ([link]3:24[/link]). His resurrection proves that God's requirements were satisfied by His death for us, that we are justified by God because of His death, and that in Him, the resurrected One, we are accepted before God. Furthermore, as the resurrected One, He is in us to live for us a life that can be justified by God and is always acceptable to God.

verse.text: Therefore having been [xref]a[/xref]justified out of faith, we have [xref]b[/xref]peace [note]1[/note]toward God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
verse.note: Our journey into God through our being justified out of faith has not yet been completed; thus, Paul used the word [i]toward,[/i] not [i]with.[/i] Grace is for our standing ([link]v. 2[/link]), and peace is for our walk.

verse.text: Through whom also we have obtained access by [note]1[/note]faith into this [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace in which we [note]3[/note]stand and [note]4[/note]boast because of the [note]5[/note][xref]b[/xref]hope of the [xref]c[/xref]glory of God.
verse.note: The very faith that justifies us and cuts off the flesh with its natural energy and effort also gives us access into God's grace. If we remain in the flesh with its natural effort, we will neither know nor enjoy the grace of God; but if we live by faith, we will enter into the full enjoyment of God's grace.

Grace is the Triune God Himself, processed that we may enter into Him and enjoy Him. Grace here, in the deepest sense, is the Triune God as our enjoyment. It is more than unmerited favor and more than mere outward blessing. We are not merely under God's blessing; we are in His grace (see note [link]2[sup]3[/sup][/link]).
Faith first gives us access into grace, then, a solid standing in grace.
[i]Boast[/i] in Greek also has the meaning of [i]exult.[/i] This indicates our enjoyment of God. (So in the next verse.)

Our hope is that we will be brought into the glory of God, that is, into His expression. This will be fully realized in the coming millennial kingdom, where Christ will be revealed as our glory. Today we are in the hope of this coming glory (see note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 11[/link]).
verse.xref: [link]Rom. 1:7[/link]; [link]3:24[/link]; [link]5:15[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]20[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]6:14[/link]; [link]16:20[/link]; [link]John 1:14[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:6[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]2:5[/link], [link]7[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:14[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]; [link]3:7[/link]; [link]4:10[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 3:18[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:1[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:10[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 12:9[/link]; [link]13:14[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:4[/link]; [link]6:18[/link]

verse.text: And not only so, but we also boast in our [note]1[/note]tribulations, knowing that tribulation produces [note]2[/note]endurance;
verse.note: Tribulations are part of the "all things" in [link]8:28[/link] that God causes to work together for good that we might be sanctified, transformed, and conformed to the image of His Son, who has entered into glory. Because of this, we can receive tribulations as the sweet visitation and incarnation of grace and thereby boast in them. Through tribulations the killing effect of the cross of Christ on our natural being is applied in us by the Holy Spirit, making the way for the God of resurrection to add Himself to us (see [link]2 Cor. 4:16-18[/link]).
Meaning [i]persistence.[/i] Persistence is the product of patience plus suffering.

verse.text: And endurance, [note]1[/note]approvedness; and approvedness, [xref]a[/xref]hope;
verse.note: Approvedness is an approved quality or attribute resulting from the enduring and experiencing of tribulation and testing.

verse.text: And hope does not put [i]us[/i] to shame, because the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love of God has been [xref]b[/xref]poured out in our [xref]c[/xref]hearts through the Holy Spirit, who has been given to us.
verse.note: The love of God is God Himself ([link]1 John 4:8[/link], [link]16[/link]). God has poured out this love in our hearts with the Holy Spirit, who has been given to us, as the motivating power within us, that we may more than conquer in all our tribulations (see note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]). Therefore, when we endure any kind of tribulation, we are not put to shame.

verse.text: For while we were yet [note]1[/note]weak, in due time Christ [xref]a[/xref]died for the ungodly.
verse.note: I.e., impotent; unable to please God.

verse.text: For scarcely for a righteous man will anyone die, though perhaps for the good man someone would even dare to die.
But God commends His own [xref]a[/xref]love to us in that while we were yet sinners, Christ [xref]b[/xref]died for us.
Much more then, having now been justified in His [xref]a[/xref]blood, we will be saved through Him from the [xref]b[/xref]wrath.

For if we, being enemies, were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reconciled to God through the death of His Son, [note]2[/note]much more we will be [note]3[/note]saved [note]4[/note]in His [note]5[/note][xref]b[/xref]life, having been reconciled,
verse.note: Propitiation and forgiveness of sins are adequate for a sinner but not for an enemy. An enemy needs reconciliation, which includes propitiation and forgiveness but goes further, even to resolving the conflict between two parties. Our being reconciled to God is based on Christ's redemption and was accomplished through God's justification ([link]3:24[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:18-19[/link]). Reconciliation is the result of being justified out of faith.

[link]Verse 10[/link] of this chapter points out that God's full salvation revealed in this book consists of two sections: one section is the redemption accomplished for us by Christ's death, and the other section is the saving afforded us by Christ's life. The first four chapters of this book discourse comprehensively regarding the redemption accomplished by Christ's death, whereas the last twelve chapters speak in detail concerning the saving afforded by Christ's life. Before [link]5:11[/link], Paul shows us that we are saved because we have been redeemed, justified, and reconciled to God. However, we have not yet been saved to the extent of being sanctified, transformed, and conformed to the image of God's Son. Redemption, justification, and reconciliation, which are accomplished outside of us by the death of Christ, redeem us objectively; sanctification, transformation, and conformation, which are accomplished within us by the working of Christ's life, save us subjectively. Objective redemption redeems us positionally from condemnation and eternal punishment; subjective salvation saves us dispositionally from our old man, our self, and our natural life.
Being reconciled to God through Christ's death is an accomplished matter, but being saved in His life from so many negative things unto glorification is a daily matter.

To be saved in Christ's life is to be saved in Christ Himself as life. He dwells in us, and we are organically one with Him. By the growth of His life in us, we will enjoy His full salvation to the uttermost. Redemption, justification, and reconciliation are for the purpose of bringing us into union with Christ so that He can save us in His life unto glorification ([link]8:30[/link]).

Implying resurrection. After death is spoken of in the first part of this verse, life is mentioned. Christ died that He might be our life in resurrection. We have been saved by Christ's death from God's eternal judgment and eternal punishment, but we are still being saved by Christ's life in His resurrection. The life here, the power in [link]1:16[/link], and the Spirit in [link]ch. 8[/link] refer to different aspects of the processed Triune God.

verse.text: And not only so, but also [note]1[/note]boasting in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received the [xref]a[/xref]reconciliation.
verse.note: To boast in God means to have God as our boast and our exultation, indicating that God is our enjoyment and our rejoicing. See note [link]2[sup]4[/sup][/link]. It is in boasting, in exulting, and in enjoying in this way that we are being saved in the life of Christ.

verse.text: Therefore just as through [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]one man [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sin entered into the [note]3[/note]world, and [xref]c[/xref]through sin, [note]4[/note]death; and thus [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]death passed on to all men because all have sinned —
verse.note: I.e., Adam, the first man, the father of the entire human race, who brought in death through sin. In contrast to Adam is Christ, the second man ([link]1 Cor. 15:47[/link]), who brought in life through righteousness ([link]vv. 17-18[/link]).

Up to [link]v. 11[/link] sins (plural) have been dealt with. From [link]v. 12[/link] sin (singular) is dealt with. It seems that in [link]chs. 5-8[/link] sin is personified. Sin is not merely an action; it is like a person who can enter ([link]v. 12[/link]), reign ([link]v. 21[/link]), lord it over people ([link]6:14[/link]), deceive and kill people ([link]7:11[/link]), and dwell in people and cause them to do things against their will ([link]7:17[/link], [link]20[/link]). It is quite alive ([link]7:9[/link]) and exceedingly active; hence, it must be the evil nature of Satan, the evil one, who, having injected himself into man through Adam's fall, has now become the very sinful nature dwelling, acting, and working in fallen man. This indwelling, personified sinful nature is the root of all the outward sinful acts.
Or, people of the world; referring to mankind ([link]John 1:29[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]).

Death is the ultimate result of man's fall. Man's spirit was deadened first, and eventually his body also died. Death and sin cannot be separated; where one is, the other will be found. Furthermore, death is not only a physical suffering in the future; it is something in which man is involved daily.

verse.text: For until the law sin was in the world, but sin is not [note]1[/note]charged to one's account when there is no [xref]a[/xref]law.
verse.note: Sin existed before the law was given, but it was not manifested to man or charged to his account by God before that time.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]death reigned from [note]2[/note]Adam until Moses, even over those who had not sinned after the likeness of Adam's [note]3[/note]transgression, [xref]b[/xref]who is a [note]4[/note]type of Him who was to come.
verse.note: Death is mentioned many times in [link]chs. 5-8[/link] ([link]vv. 12[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]6:9[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]7:5[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]8:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]38[/link]). Life also is mentioned repeatedly in these chapters ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]17-18[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]6:4[/link], [link]22-23[/link]; [link]7:10[/link]; [link]8:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]10-11[/link], [link]38[/link]). These two key words form two contrasting lines through [link]chs. 5-8[/link], the line of life and the line of death, showing that man is at the center of a triangular situation between God and Satan, life and death. Thus, [link]chs. 5-8[/link] of Romans can be called the kernel of the Bible, showing its entire theme in a concrete and detailed way.

From Adam to Moses was the dispensation before law (without law); from Moses to Christ ([link]John 1:17[/link]) was the dispensation of law; from Christ's first coming to the restoration of all things ([link]Acts 3:20-21[/link]) is the dispensation of grace; and from Christ's second coming to the end of the millennium ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]) is the dispensation of the kingdom. These dispensations are used by God to accomplish His work of the new creation in the old creation.

In this chapter the words [i]transgression, offense,[/i] and [i]disobedience[/i] all refer to the fall of Adam, which consisted in his leaving life and choosing death. Adam forsook the tree of life, which denotes God as life, to pursue the tree of knowledge, which signifies Satan as the source of death ([link]Gen. 2:8-9[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]3:1-7[/link]).

Adam was the head of the old collective man (mankind). Whatever he did and whatever happened to him is participated in by all mankind. In this respect he is a type of Christ, who is the Head of the new corporate man, the church ([link]Eph. 2:15-16[/link]). Whatever He did and whatever happened to Him is participated in by all the members of His Body, the church ([link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]).

verse.text: But [i]it is[/i] not [i]that[/i] as the offense was, so also the gracious gift is; for if by the offense of the [xref]a[/xref]one the many died, much more the grace of God and the free gift in grace of the one [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]man Jesus Christ have [note]2[/note]abounded to the many.
verse.note: Christ our Redeemer was fully a man and was fully God as well (see [link]9:5[/link]). Grace with all its gifts abounded in the humanity of Christ.
Grace not only abounds ([link]v. 17[/link]) and multiplies (superabounds — [link]v. 20[/link]) but also reigns ([link]v. 21[/link]). Only a living person can reign.

verse.text: And [i]it is[/i] not [i]that[/i] as through one who sinned, [i]so also[/i] the free [note]1[/note]gift is; for the judgment was out of one [i]offense[/i] unto condemnation, but the gracious gift is out of many offenses unto [xref]a[/xref]justification.
verse.note: Referring to the gift of righteousness, which we have received ([link]v. 17[/link]). This indicates that the righteousness given to us by God is a gift.

verse.text: For if, by the offense of the one, death reigned through the one, much more those who receive the [note]1[/note]abundance of grace and of the gift of [note]2[/note]righteousness will [note]3[/note]reign in [note]4[/note]life through the One, Jesus Christ.
verse.note: Those who receive the abundant grace are able to reign in life, for life issues out of the abundance of grace.

The gift of righteousness erases judgment. Judgment comes from sin, but righteousness comes from grace. Righteousness always accompanies grace and is its result. Subjective righteousness ([link]4:25b[/link]) comes from grace ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]19[/link]), and grace comes from objective righteousness ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]).

The life we have received does not merely save us from a few things; rather, it enthrones us as kings to reign over all things. This is much higher than being saved in life. We have received righteousness objectively, but we still need to continually receive the abundance of grace so that we can reign in life subjectively. This reigning is defined in [link]chs. 6-16[/link]; all the matters expounded there are the issue not of our endeavoring but of our receiving the abundance of grace.

[i]Life[/i] here, and in [link]vv. 10[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]6:4[/link]; and [link]8:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]10[/link], refers to the eternal, divine, uncreated life of God ([i]zoe[/i]), which is Christ Himself as life to us ([link]John 11:25[/link]; [link]14:6[/link]; [link]Col. 3:4[/link]). It is different from both our physical life ([i]bios[/i] — [link]Luke 8:14[/link]) and our soulish life ([i]psuche[/i] — [link]Matt. 16:25-26[/link]; [link]John 12:25[/link]). This eternal life of God is the main element of the divine grace that has been given to us, and in this eternal life we can reign.

verse.text: So then as [i]it was[/i] through one offense unto condemnation to all men, so also [i]it was[/i] through one [note]1[/note]righteous act unto justification of [note]2[/note]life to all men.
verse.note: Christ's righteous act of dying on the cross resulted in justification of life. [link]Verse 21[/link] says that grace reigns through righteousness unto life. These two verses show that life comes as the result of righteousness (see [link]8:10[/link]).

Life is the goal of God's salvation; thus, justification is "of life." Justification is not an end in itself; it is for life. Through justification we have come up to the standard of God's righteousness and correspond with it, so that now He can impart His life to us. Justification changes our outward position; life changes our inward disposition. Justification unto life indicates that life is the focus of this chapter and that the organic union of life is an issue of justification.

verse.text: For just as through the disobedience of one man the many were [note]1[/note]constituted sinners, so also through the [note]2[/note]obedience of the One the many will be [note]1[/note]constituted righteous.
verse.note: Whether we are sinners or are righteous depends not on our actions but on our inward constitution. Through his fall Adam received an element that was not created by God. This was the satanic nature, which became the constituting essence and main element of fallen man. It is this constituting essence and element that constituted all men sinners. We are not sinners because we sin; we sin because we are sinners. Whether we do good or evil, in Adam we have been constituted sinners. This is due to our inward element, not our outward actions.[br][br]In contrast, Christ constitutes us righteous. When He, the living God, comes into our being as grace, we are constituted righteous. He becomes the constituting essence and element in us that can transform us from sinners into sons of God. He alone is able to accomplish such a reconstituting work.
Christ's death on the cross was the highest expression of His obedience and was regarded by God a righteous act ([link]v. 18[/link]; see [link]Phil. 2:8[/link]).

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]law entered in alongside that the offense might [note]1[/note]abound; but where sin [note]1[/note]abounded, grace has superabounded,
verse.note: The law causes sin to abound, that is, to become evident and recognizable to man. In this way man's sinfulness is fully exposed.

verse.text: In order that just as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sin reigned in death, so also grace might reign through [note]2[/note]righteousness unto [xref]b[/xref]eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verse.note: Sin reigns by the authority of death and brings in death by its reign. Thus, a sinner must die.

Righteousness is the footing, the base, and the means for God to dispense Himself to us as grace. This righteousness gives us the ground to claim Christ as our grace. By giving grace to us, God manifests His righteousness (see [link]1:17[/link]). Furthermore, the power of this grace operates in us and produces subjective righteousness, making us right with God, with others, and even with ourselves; and it not only subdues sin but also overcomes Satan and death in our being. Thus grace reigns through righteousness, resulting in eternal life.

verse.text: What then shall we say? [xref]a[/xref]Should we continue in sin that [xref]b[/xref]grace may abound?
Absolutely not! We who have [xref]a[/xref]died to sin, how shall we still live in it?
Or are you ignorant that all of us who have been [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptized into [note]2[/note]Christ Jesus have been [note]1[/note]baptized into [note]3[/note]His death?
verse.note: Baptism is not a form or a ritual; it signifies our identification with Christ. Through baptism we are immersed into Christ, taking Him as our realm, that we may be united with Him as one in His death and resurrection.

We were born in the sphere of Adam, the first man ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link], [link]47[/link]), but through baptism we have been transferred into the sphere of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]), the second man ([link]1 Cor. 15:47[/link]).

When we are baptized into Christ, we are baptized into His death. His death has separated us from the world and the satanic power of darkness and has terminated our natural life, our old nature, our self, our flesh, and even our entire history.

verse.text: We have been [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]buried therefore with Him through [note]2[/note]baptism into His death, in order that just as Christ was [xref]b[/xref]raised from the dead through the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]glory of the Father, so also we might [note]4[/note]walk in [xref]d[/xref]newness of [xref]e[/xref]life.
verse.note: Our old man has been crucified with Christ ([link]v. 6[/link]), and it has been buried with Him through baptism into death. In the natural realm, a person first dies and then is buried; but Paul's word indicates that in the spiritual realm, we are first buried and then die. We do not die directly; we enter into Christ's death through baptism.
Christ and His death are one. Apart from Him we could never be baptized into His death, for the element of His effective death is found only in Him, the resurrected, all-inclusive One.
Referring to the manifestation of divinity.

After baptism we become a new person in resurrection. Resurrection is not only a future state; it is also a present process. To walk in newness of life means to live today in the realm of resurrection and to reign in life. This kind of living deals with all that is of Adam in us until we are fully transformed and conformed to the image of Christ ([link]8:29[/link]).

verse.text: For if we have [note]1[/note]grown together with [i]Him[/i] in the [note]2[/note]likeness of His death, indeed we will also be [note]3[/note][i]in the[/i] [note]2[/note][i]likeness[/i] of His resurrection,
verse.note: This denotes an organic union in which growth takes place, so that one partakes of the life and characteristics of the other. In the organic union with Christ, whatever Christ passed through has become our history. His death and resurrection are now ours because we are in Him and are organically joined to Him. This is grafting ([link]11:24[/link]). Such a grafting (1) discharges all our negative elements, (2) resurrects our God-created faculties, (3) uplifts our faculties, (4) enriches our faculties, and (5) saturates our entire being to transform us.
The likeness of Christ's death is the baptism mentioned in [link]v. 4[/link]; the likeness of Christ's resurrection is the newness of life mentioned in [link]v. 4[/link].
