This does not refer to a future, objective resurrection but to the present process of growth. When we were baptized, we grew together with Christ in the likeness of His death; now, through His death we are growing into His resurrection. Just as the element of Christ's death is found only in Him, so the element of Christ's resurrection is found only in Christ Himself. He Himself is resurrection ([link]John 11:25[/link]). After experiencing a proper baptism, we continue to grow in and with Christ in the likeness of His resurrection, that is, to walk in newness of life.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Knowing this, that our [note]2[/note]old man has been [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]crucified with [i]Him[/i] in order that the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]body of sin might be [note]5[/note]annulled, that we should no longer serve sin as slaves;
verse.note: In Greek, [i]knowing[/i] here refers to the outward, objective knowledge; [i]knowing[/i] in [link]v. 9[/link] and [i]know[/i] in [link]v. 16[/link] refer to the inward, subjective consciousness.

Referring to the natural life in our soul. The old man is our very being, which was created by God but became fallen through sin, and it is the same as the "I" in [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]. It is not the soul itself but the life of the soul, which has been counted by God as hopeless and has been put on the cross and crucified with Christ. Formerly, our soul acted as an independent person, with the old man as its life and personality; now, since the old man has been crucified, our soul should act only as an organ of Christ and should be under the control of our spirit, having Christ as its life.
See note [link]24[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link].

The body indwelt, occupied, corrupted, possessed, utilized, and enslaved by sin, so that it does sinful things. This body of sin is very active and full of strength to commit sins; it differs from "the body of this death" mentioned in [link]7:24[/link], which is weak and powerless in the things of God. The body of sin is not the sinning person but the sinning instrument utilized by the old man to express himself by committing sins, thereby causing the body of sin to become the flesh. Hence, [i]the body of sin[/i] in this verse and [i]the flesh of sin[/i] in [link]8:3[/link] refer to the same thing.

Or, unemployed, jobless, inactive. Because the old man has been crucified with Christ, the body that had been utilized by him as the instrument for sinning now has nothing to do; it is unemployed, jobless. Thus, we have been freed from sin ([link]vv. 18-22[/link]) and no longer need to be under the bondage of sin to serve sin as slaves.

verse.text: For he who has died is justified from [note]1[/note]sin.
verse.note: Both the nature of sin with its power and its pain, and the sinful acts with their history and their judgment.

verse.text: Now if we have [xref]a[/xref]died [note]1[/note]with Christ, we believe that we will also [xref]b[/xref]live [note]1[/note]with Him,
verse.note: This again shows our organic union with Christ in His death and His resurrection.

verse.text: Knowing that Christ, having been raised from the dead, [xref]a[/xref]dies [note]1[/note]no more; death lords it over Him no more.
verse.note: In His resurrection Christ is transcendent over corruption and death. Since we are one with Him in this resurrection, we also are transcendent over corruption and death.

verse.text: For [i]the death[/i] which He died, He died to sin once for all; but [i]the life[/i] which He lives, He lives to God.
So also you, [note]1[/note]reckon yourselves to be [xref]a[/xref]dead to sin, but living to God in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: Or, consider. Reckoning is not a technique but a spontaneous believing, a spontaneous considering, produced by seeing the facts that are revealed in this chapter. We must see and believe the facts, recognize them, and, according to them, reckon ourselves dead to sin and living to God.[br][br]Reckoning, however, is not the cause of death and cannot by itself execute the death of Christ within us. Only by the enjoyment of the Spirit, who is revealed in [link]ch. 8[/link], will we experience Christ's all-inclusive and effective death and His resurrection and its power, which are revealed here in this chapter. This chapter shows the objective facts accomplished by Christ for us; these need our believing and reckoning. [link]Chapter 8[/link] shows the subjective work of the Spirit in making the facts accomplished by Christ real in our practical experience; this needs our fellowship with and enjoyment of Him. The facts spoken of in this chapter can become our experience only in the Spirit revealed in [link]ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Do not let [xref]a[/xref]sin therefore reign in your mortal body so that you obey [note]2[/note]the body's [xref]b[/xref]lusts;
verse.note: This is to reject sin and to cooperate with the Spirit of God.
Lit., its (referring to [i]body).[/i]

verse.text: Neither [xref]a[/xref]present your [xref]b[/xref]members as [xref]c[/xref]weapons of unrighteousness to sin, but [note]1[/note]present yourselves to God as alive from the dead, and your members as [note]2[/note]weapons of righteousness to God.
verse.note: Presenting ourselves and our members to God is the result of seeing the facts of our having been crucified and resurrected with Christ and of reckoning ourselves dead and living according to these facts.
Or, instruments. Our members are not merely instruments but are weapons of righteousness to fight the battle in the war between righteousness and unrighteousness.

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]sin will not [note]1[/note]lord it over you, [note]2[/note]for you are [note]3[/note]not under the law but under [xref]b[/xref]grace.
verse.note: Sin, here personified, lords it over us through the lusts of our body ([link]v. 12[/link]).

That we are not under the law but under grace is the reason sin cannot lord it over us. This gives us the position to reject sin. Sin no longer has any right to make claims upon us, but we have the full right to reject sin and its power. By rejecting sin and taking sides with the resurrected Christ, we present ourselves and our members as slaves to righteousness that the divine life may work within us to sanctify us, not only positionally but also dispositionally, with the holy nature of God.

This does not make us lawless, as some were during the time of the church's degradation ([link]Jude 4[/link]). The law referred to in this verse is the law given by Moses, which has been replaced by the inward laws in the new covenant ([link]Heb. 10:16[/link]). Just as [link]chs. 5[/link] and [link book="Rom."]6[/link] explain that we are now under grace, [link]chs. 7[/link] and [link book="Rom."]8[/link] explain how it can be that we are not under the law.

verse.text: What then? [xref]a[/xref]Should we sin, because we are not under the law but under grace? Absolutely not!

Do you not know that to whom you present yourselves as slaves for obedience, [i]his[/i] slaves you are whom you obey, whether of sin [note]1[/note]unto death or of obedience [note]1[/note]unto righteousness?
verse.note: [i]Unto[/i] may be interpreted [i]resulting in,[/i] and so in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: But thanks be to God that though you were [xref]a[/xref]slaves of sin, you have obeyed from the heart the form of teaching into which you were delivered.
And having been [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]freed from sin, you were enslaved to righteousness.
verse.note: This occurred as a result of the crucifixion of the old man ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: I speak in human [i]terms[/i] because of the weakness of your flesh. For just as you presented your members as slaves to uncleanness and lawlessness unto lawlessness, so now [xref]a[/xref]present your members as slaves to righteousness [note]1[/note]unto [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanctification.
verse.note: Righteousness ushers us into sanctification. If we present ourselves as slaves to righteousness and our members as weapons of righteousness, Christ as the eternal life within us will have the ground to work in us and saturate our inward parts with Himself. Thus we will be sanctified spontaneously; we will be made holy spontaneously in our inward parts by Christ's saturating.

Sanctification (see note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]) involves not only a change in position, that is, a separation from a common, worldly position to a position for God, as illustrated in [link]Matt. 23:17[/link], [link]19[/link] and in [link]1 Tim. 4:3-5[/link]; it involves also a transformation in disposition, that is, a transformation from the natural disposition to a spiritual one by Christ as the life-giving Spirit saturating all the inward parts of our being with God's nature of holiness, as mentioned in [link]Rom. 12:2[/link] and [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link].

verse.text: For when you were [xref]a[/xref]slaves of sin, you were free with regard to righteousness.
What fruit then did you have at that time? Things of which you are now ashamed, for the end of those things is death.
But now, having been [xref]a[/xref]freed from sin and enslaved to God, you have your fruit unto [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanctification, and the end, [xref]c[/xref]eternal [note]2[/note]life.
verse.note: See note [link]19[sup]2[/sup][/link].

The dispositional sanctification spoken of in this chapter not only comes out of life ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]23[/link]) but also results in life and brings more life to us that we may enjoy the riches of the divine life.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note]wages of sin is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]death, but the gift of God is [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verse.note: Wages are a payment according to righteousness, based on the work that a person performs. In the eyes of God, all man's behavior apart from God is sin and is man's work, and the wages it earns is death.

Death comes from sin and is its result. The death mentioned here, however, is not only physical death and eternal death, but the death in which man is entangled daily. See note [link]12[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

Eternal life is the very life of the Triune God Himself. This life has been imparted into us on the basis of our having been justified by God, and it is now spreading throughout our being through sanctification and transformation. This will result in our being conformed to the Lord's image and our being brought into the Lord's glory, that we may be made suitable to have a part in the manifestation of His glory ([link]Col. 3:4[/link]).

verse.text: Or are you ignorant, brothers (for I speak to those who know the law), that the [note]1[/note]law lords it over the man as long as he lives?
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-6[/link] continue [link]6:14[/link] to explain how it is that we are not under the law. On one hand, the law continues to exist, for God has not recalled, annulled, or abolished it. On the other hand, because of the crucifixion of our old man ([link]6:6[/link]), who is the first husband mentioned in these verses, we are no longer under the law and no longer have anything to do with it. Instead, we have become the wife of Christ; that is, we have become those who depend on Christ.

verse.text: For the married woman is bound by the [note]1[/note]law to her [note]2[/note]husband while he is living; but if the husband dies, she is discharged from the [note]1[/note]law regarding the husband.
verse.note: Because fallen man left his proper position as God's wife and desired to be the husband (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link]), God gave him the law, which he cannot possibly keep. The law is intended not for the wife but for the husband, and the law was given not that it might be kept but that the old man might be exposed ([link]v. 5[/link]; [link]3:20[/link]; [link]5:20[/link]). Accordingly, this verse refers to the law as "the law regarding the husband."

The husband here (the first husband) is not the flesh or the law but the old man mentioned in [link]6:6[/link], who has been crucified with Christ. Thus, [link]vv. 1-6[/link] correspond with [link]6:6[/link].

verse.text: So then if, while the husband is living, she is joined to [note]1[/note]another man, she will be called an adulteress; but if the husband dies, she is free from the law, so that she is not an adulteress, though she is joined to [note]1[/note]another man.
verse.note: Referring to the second husband mentioned in these verses, who is Christ.

verse.text: So then, my brothers, [note]1[/note]you also [xref]a[/xref]have been made dead to the law through the body of Christ so that [note]1[/note]you might be [note]2[/note]joined to [xref]b[/xref]another, to Him who has been raised from the dead, that we might [note]3[/note]bear fruit to God.
verse.note: Since our old man, who was the old husband, has been crucified with Christ ([link]6:6[/link]), we are freed from his law and are joined to the new Husband, Christ, the ever-living One. As believers, we have two statuses. The first [i]you[/i] in this verse refers to us in our old status as the fallen old man, who left the original position of a wife dependent on God and took the self-assuming position of husband and head, independent of God. The second [i]you[/i] in this verse refers to us in our new status as the regenerated new man, restored to our original and proper position as the genuine wife to God ([link]Isa. 54:5[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:3[/link]), dependent on Him and taking Him as our Head. We no longer have the old status of the husband, for we have been crucified. We now have only the new status of the proper wife, in which we take Christ as our Husband, and should no longer live according to the old man, i.e., no longer take the old man as our husband.
This joining indicates that in our new status as a wife, we have an organic union in person, name, life, and existence with Christ in His resurrection.

As the regenerated new man and the wife to Christ, everything we are and do is now related to God, and God is brought forth by us as the fruit, the overflow, of our life. This is in contrast to the fruit born to death ([link]v. 5[/link]), which was previously brought forth by us as the old man, the old husband.

verse.text: For when we were in the flesh, the passions for sins, which [i]acted[/i] through the law, operated in our members to bear fruit to death.

But now we have been [note]1[/note]discharged from the law, having died to that in which we were held, so that we [note]2[/note]serve in [note]3[/note]newness of [note]4[/note]spirit and not in oldness of letter.
verse.note: Since the old man has been crucified, the regenerated new man is now free from the law of the old man ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:19[/link]). Since the law was given to the old husband, the old man, not to the wife, and since the old husband, the old man, died on the cross, the new man, the wife, has been discharged from his law.
Lit., serve as slaves.

In [link]6:4[/link], newness of life issues from our being identified with Christ's resurrection and is for our walk in our daily life. Here, newness of spirit issues from our being discharged from the law and being joined to the resurrected Christ, and is for our service to God. Thus, both newness of spirit and newness of life are results of the crucifixion of the old man.

Referring to our regenerated human spirit, in which the Lord as the Spirit dwells ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). Everything that is related to our regenerated spirit is new, and everything that comes out of our spirit is new. Our regenerated spirit is a source of newness because the Lord, the life of God, and the Holy Spirit are there (see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]).

verse.text: What then shall we say? Is the law sin? Absolutely not! But [note]1[/note]I did not [xref]a[/xref]know sin except through the [note]2[/note]law; for neither did I know coveting, except the law had said, [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]"You shall not covet."
verse.note: In [link]vv. 7-25[/link] Paul used his own experience, which he had before he believed in the Lord, to illustrate the wretchedness of trying to do good under the law in order to please God. Neither the human spirit nor the Spirit of God is mentioned in this section; rather, the will and the mind of the human soul ([link]vv. 19[/link], [link]23[/link]), which attempt to please God with the good of the natural life ([link]vv. 18-19[/link], [link]21[/link]), are referred to. Although this is the situation of an unsaved person, nearly all Christians pass through this kind of experience after they are saved.

The law portrays God and defines Him ([link]Lev. 19:2[/link]). Accordingly, it places many demands and requirements on fallen man, and in so doing it identifies sin as sin and leads man to the knowledge of sin ([link]3:20[/link]; [link]4:15[/link]; [link]5:20[/link]). In this way man is both exposed and subdued by the law ([link]3:19[/link]).

The tenth commandment, "You shall not covet," is not related to outward conduct, but rather to the sin within man, mainly in his thoughts. This shows that man's problem is with the sin that indwells him, not just with outward sinful acts.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]sin, seizing the opportunity through the commandment, worked out in me coveting of every kind; for without the law sin is dead.
verse.note: This chapter, especially in this verse and in [link]vv. 11[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]20[/link], indicates that sin is a person, the embodiment of Satan, and is living and acting within us.

verse.text: And I was alive without the law once; but when the commandment came, sin revived and I died.
And the commandment, which was unto life, this very [i]commandment[/i] was found to me to be unto [note]1[/note]death.
verse.note: Referring to our being put to death by the curse and condemnation brought to us, both in our conscience and before God, by sin through the law ([link]4:15[/link]; [link]5:13[/link], [link]20[/link]).

verse.text: For sin, seizing the opportunity [note]1[/note]through the commandment, [xref]a[/xref]deceived me and [xref]b[/xref]through it killed [i]me.[/i]
verse.note: The law is the instrument through which sin deceives and kills men. The power of sin is the law ([link]1 Cor. 15:56[/link]). This fact should warn us not to turn to the law to try to keep it, for in so doing we give sin the opportunity to deceive and kill us.

verse.text: So then the law is holy, and the commandment holy and righteous and good.

Did then that which is good become death to me? Absolutely not! But sin [i]did,[/i] that it might [note]1[/note]be shown to be sin by working out death in me through that which is good, that sin through the commandment might become exceedingly sinful.
verse.note: Lit., appear.

verse.text: For we [note]1[/note]know that the law is [note]2[/note]spiritual; but I am [note]3[/note]fleshy, sold under sin.
verse.note: The inward, subjective consciousness. See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
I.e., the same in essence, nature, and substance as God, who is Spirit ([link]John 4:24[/link]).

Paul saw that he was contrary to all that is portrayed by the law. It is spiritual, holy, righteous, and good; he was fleshy, common and defiled, unjust, and evil. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 3[/link].

verse.text: For what I work out, I [note]1[/note]do not acknowledge; for what I will, this I do not practice; but what I hate, this I do.
verse.note: Lit., do not know; i.e., do not acknowledge, do not approve of. Paul did not allow, approve of, or acknowledge his wrong action, for it issued from his flesh, which served the law of sin against his mind and against his will.

verse.text: But if what I do not will, this I do, I agree with the law that it is good.
Now then [i]it is[/i] [xref]a[/xref]no longer I [i]that[/i] work it out but sin that [note]1[/note]dwells in me.
verse.note: Lit., houses itself. Sin does not merely abide or remain within us for a time; it makes its home in us.

verse.text: For I [note]1[/note]know that in me, that is, in my [note]2[/note]flesh, [note]3[/note]nothing good dwells; for [note]4[/note]to will is present with me, but to work out the good is not.
verse.note: The inward, subjective consciousness. See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

The flesh here is the fallen and corrupted human body with all its lusts. This flesh was not created by God but is a mixture of God's creature and sin, which is the life of Satan, the evil one. God created man's body a pure vessel, but this vessel was corrupted and transmuted into the flesh by Satan's injecting himself into it at the time of the fall. Now Satan as sin personified is in man's flesh, making his home there and ruling as an illegal master, overruling man and forcing him to do things that he dislikes. It is this indwelling sin, which is the unchangeable evil nature, that constitutes all men sinners ([link]5:19[/link]).

Here Paul was careful to say that it is in the flesh, not in man's whole being, that nothing good dwells. Good does exist in other parts of man's being. The will desires to please God ([link]vv. 18-21[/link]) according to the good law in the mind ([link]vv. 22-23[/link]), but it is impossible to perform this good through the body, for the body has become the flesh, where sin dwells.
To will to do good is to turn to the law. The law of good in our mind ([link]vv. 22-23[/link]) corresponds with the law of God and responds to its demands by trying to keep it.

verse.text: For I do not do the good which I will; but the evil which I do not will, this I practice.
But if what I do not will, this I do, [i]it is[/i] [xref]a[/xref]no longer I [i]that[/i] work it out but sin that dwells in me.
I find then [note]1[/note]the law with me who wills to do the good, that is, the [note]2[/note]evil is present with me.
verse.note: According to the fact mentioned in [link]v. 20[/link], Paul discovered that the law of sin was the sin that dwelt in him and the evil that was present with him. In [link]v. 23[/link] he realized that this law was the law of sin in his members.

The Greek word means [i]that which is evil in character.[/i] This must be the evil life, nature, and character of Satan himself, who is the indwelling sin in us. When sin is dormant within us, it is merely sin, but when it is aroused in us by our willing to do the good, it becomes "the evil."

verse.text: For I delight in the [note]1[/note]law of God according to the inner man,
verse.note: Referring to the written law of God.

verse.text: But I see a different [note]1[/note]law in my members, [note]2[/note]warring against the law of my mind and making me a [note]3[/note]captive to the [xref]a[/xref]law of sin which is in my members.
verse.note: There are three different laws in the three different parts of the believer's being. As revealed in [link]chs. 7[/link] and [link book="Rom."]8[/link], these three laws derive from the three parties in the universe. The law of sin and death in the believer's members ([link]v. 23[/link]), that is, in his body, derives from Satan, who as sin dwells in the believer's flesh. The law of good in the believer's mind ([link]v. 23[/link]), that is, in his soul, derives from the natural human life, that is, from man himself. The law of the Spirit of life in the believer's spirit derives from God, who as the Spirit dwells in his spirit ([link]8:2[/link], [link]16[/link]). These three parties with the three laws are now present in the believer in much the same way that they (God, man, and Satan) were present in the Garden of Eden ([link]Gen. 3[/link]). In addition to the three laws within the believer, there is the law of God outside of him ([link]vv. 22[/link], [link]25[/link]).

The warfare here is between the law of sin in the members of our body and the law of good in the mind of our soul. It is absolutely a matter of sin in our flesh fighting against good in our natural being; it is not at all related to our spirit or the Spirit of God. Hence, it is different from the warfare in [link]Gal. 5:16-25[/link], between our spirit, which is mingled with the Spirit of God, and the flesh.
A person who is independent of God cannot deal with the law of sin in the flesh, for this law is the powerful person of Satan himself.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Wretched man that I am! Who will deliver me from [note]2[/note]the body of [note]3[/note]this death?
verse.note: To attempt to keep the law by the flesh results in death and wretchedness. Man has become fleshy, sold under sin ([link]v. 14[/link]). In man's flesh nothing good dwells ([link]v. 18[/link]), and man is unable to master sin ([link]vv. 15-20[/link]). If man in such a condition tries to fulfill the law of God, he will surely fail.

In [link]6:6[/link] our fallen body is called "the body of sin." Here it is termed "the body of this death." The body of sin is strong in sinning against God, but the body of this death is weak in acting to please God. Sin energizes the fallen body to sin, whereas death utterly weakens and disables the corrupted body, so that it cannot keep God's commandments.

The death caused by sin through the weapon of the law, the death of being defeated, the death of trying to keep the law to please God but instead being made a captive by the law of sin in our members. This is the death that is working in our flesh this very moment.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Thanks be to God, through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then [note]1[/note]with the mind I myself [note]2[/note]serve the law of God, but with the flesh, the [note]3[/note]law of sin.
verse.note: The phrase [i]with the mind I myself[/i] indicates that the mind, representing the self, is independently attempting to do good. Although the law of good in the mind ([link]v. 23[/link]) gives us the inclination to do good, the mind will be defeated because the law of sin in our members is stronger than the independent mind.
Lit., serve as a slave.
[i]The law of sin, sin,[/i] and [i]the evil[/i] are synonymous terms, denoting Satan, who dwells in man's fallen body.

verse.text: There is [note]1[/note]now then no [note]2[/note]condemnation to those who are [note]3[/note]in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: The phrase [i]now then no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus[/i] is a strong proof that the experience illustrated in [link]ch. 7[/link] is that of a person who is without Christ.

The condemnation implied in [link]1:18-3:20[/link] and mentioned in [link]5:16[/link], [link]18[/link] is objective, under God's righteous law, and is the result of our outward sins. The condemnation mentioned here is subjective, in our conscience, and is the result of our being inwardly defeated by the evil law of the indwelling sin, as described in [link]7:17-18[/link], [link]20-24[/link]. The blood of the crucified Christ is the remedy for objective condemnation ([link]3:25[/link]). The Spirit of life, who is Christ processed to be the life-giving Spirit and who is in our spirit, is the remedy for subjective condemnation.

In this chapter the phrase [i]in Christ[/i] refers not only to our standing, our position, in Christ, as mentioned in [link]ch. 6[/link], but also to the reality of our daily walk in our regenerated spirit. Thus, this chapter speaks of being in Christ as a term or a condition. This corresponds with being saved in His life in [link]5:10[/link].

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note]law of the [note]2[/note]Spirit of [note]3[/note]life has [note]4[/note]freed [note]5[/note]me in Christ Jesus from the [note]6[/note][xref]a[/xref]law of sin and of death.
verse.note: The law of the Spirit of life is the subject of this chapter. The Spirit and life are mentioned in this verse, but only in connection with the working of this law. Life is the content and issue of the Spirit, and the Spirit is the ultimate and consummate manifestation of the Triune God after His being processed through incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection and becoming the indwelling, life-giving Spirit, who is life to all the believers in Christ. The law that has freed us from the law of sin, which is of Satan, who dwells in the members of our fallen body ([link]Rom. 7:23[/link], [link]17[/link]), is of this Spirit of life. It is this law, not God nor the Spirit, that works in us to deliver us from the working of the law of sin in our flesh and to enable us to know God and gain God and thereby live Him out. This law of the Spirit of life is the spontaneous power of the Spirit of life. Such a spontaneous law works automatically under the condition that fulfills its requirements (see note [link]4[sup]2[/sup][/link]).[br][br]Both Satan and God, after entering into our being and dwelling in us, work within us not by outward, objective activities but by an inward, subjective law. The working of the law of the Spirit of life is the working of the processed Triune God in our spirit; this is also the working of the Triune God in us in His life.

Here law, the Spirit, and life are in contrast to law, sin, and death. The two laws are in opposition to each other, the Spirit is in opposition to sin, and life is in opposition to death. In [link]ch. 5[/link] grace, which is God embodied in us, is in opposition to sin, which is Satan embodied in us ([link]5:21[/link]). In [link]ch. 8[/link] the Spirit, who is God living in us, is in opposition to sin. Thus, the grace in [link]ch. 5[/link] is the Spirit in [link]ch. 8[/link], the very God embodied in us as grace, living and acting in us.[br][br]In the previous chapters life is mentioned a number of times ([link]1:17[/link]; [link]2:7[/link]; [link]5:10[/link], [link]17-18[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]6:4[/link], [link]22-23[/link]). In this chapter life is joined with the Spirit in the phrase [i]the Spirit of life,[/i] showing that everything regarding life in the preceding chapters is included in the Spirit in this chapter. Life belongs to the Spirit, and the Spirit is of life. These two are actually one ([link]John 6:63[/link]). The way to experience the divine, eternal, uncreated life is by the Spirit of life.

The spiritual life revealed in this chapter is fourfold. First, it was the divine life in the Spirit ([link]v. 2[/link]). Second, it became life in our spirit through regeneration ([link]v. 10[/link]). Then from our spirit it saturates our mind for the transformation of our soul, to which our mind belongs, and becomes the life in our soul ([link]v. 6[/link]). Eventually, it will permeate our body and become the life in our body ([link]v. 11[/link]), ultimately issuing in the transfiguration of our body ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]), that is, the redemption of our body ([link]v. 23[/link]).

The major function of the processed Triune God in indwelling our spirit as the law of the Spirit of life is to free us completely from Satan, who dwells in our fallen nature as the law of sin and of death ([link]7:23-25[/link]). This freeing is not only for our subjective justification but even more for our dispositional sanctification.
Some ancient MSS read, you.

The law of sin, the power to commit sin that arises spontaneously in man, causes man to become a slave of sin ([link]John 8:34[/link]). Thus, man is helpless, is controlled and manipulated by sin, and does many things against his will. The law of death, the natural power that causes man to become weak, to wither up, and to age and die, dwells in man and causes every part of man to enter into decay and death. On one hand, death disables man; on the other hand, it desensitizes man. It causes man to be disabled when he attempts to do good, and to be insensitive when he commits sins.

verse.text: For that which the [note]1[/note]law could [note]2[/note]not do, in that it was [xref]a[/xref]weak through the flesh, God, sending His own Son in the [note]3[/note]likeness of the flesh of sin and concerning sin, condemned sin in the flesh,
verse.note: In the flesh nothing good dwells ([link]7:18[/link]); only sin dwells in the flesh ([link]7:17[/link]). Furthermore, the flesh is of death ([link]7:24[/link]). Hence, no man can be justified before God out of the works of the law through the flesh ([link]3:20[/link]). Because of such a weak and impotent flesh, there is something that the law could not do.

On one hand, the law of God outside man is a law in letters, is dead, and lacks the power of life to supply man to meet its demands. On the other hand, man's body has been corrupted by Satan to become the flesh of death, and as such is incapable of keeping the law. It is because of these two factors that there is "that which the law could not do"; that is, the law is incapable of pleasing God through man's keeping of it.

The flesh is of sin, yet the Son of God became flesh ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:16[/link]). However, He was only in the likeness of the flesh and did not have the sin of the flesh ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]). This was typified by the bronze serpent lifted up by Moses for the sinful Israelites ([link]Num. 21:9[/link]; [link]John 3:14[/link]). The bronze serpent was in the form, the likeness, of the actual serpent but did not have its poison. It was such a bronze serpent that bore God's judgment for the poisoned Israelites and dealt with the serpents that poisoned them.[br][br]Although Christ did not have the sin of the flesh, He was crucified in the flesh ([link]Col. 1:22[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]). Thus, on the cross He judged Satan, who is related to the flesh, and the world, which hangs on him ([link]John 12:31[/link]; [link]16:11[/link]), thereby destroying Satan ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]). At the same time, through Christ's crucifixion in the flesh, God condemned sin, which was brought by Satan into man's flesh. As a result, it is possible for us to walk not according to the flesh but according to the spirit that the righteous requirement of the law might be fulfilled in us ([link]v. 4[/link]).

verse.text: That the righteous requirement of the law might be [note]1[/note]fulfilled in us, who do not [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]walk according to the flesh but according to the [note]3[/note]spirit.
verse.note: Not consciously kept by us through our outward endeavoring but spontaneously and unconsciously fulfilled in us by the inward working of the Spirit of life. The Spirit of life is the Spirit of Christ, and Christ corresponds with the law of God. This Spirit within us spontaneously fulfills all the righteous requirements of the law through us when we walk according to Him.

The Greek word denotes the general walk in our living. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link]. The requirements that we must fulfill in order that the law of the Spirit of life (which has already been installed in us) may work are (1) to walk according to the spirit ([link]v. 4[/link]); (2) to mind the things of the Spirit — to set the mind on the spirit ([link]vv. 5-6[/link]); (3) to put to death by the Spirit the practices of the body ([link]v. 13[/link]); (4) to be led by the Spirit as sons of God ([link]v. 14[/link]); (5) to cry to the Father in the spirit of sonship ([link]v. 15[/link]); (6) to witness that we are the children of God ([link]v. 16[/link]); and (7) to groan for the full sonship, the redemption of our body ([link]v. 23[/link]).

It is difficult to discern the word [i]spirit[/i] used in this chapter, in [link]Gal. 5[/link], and in other places in the New Testament, unless it is clearly designated to denote God's Holy Spirit or our regenerated human spirit, as in [link book="Rom." chapter="8"]v. 9[/link] and [link]v. 16[/link] of this chapter. According to the usage in the New Testament, the word [i]spirit,[/i] as used in this verse, denotes our regenerated human spirit indwelt by and mingled with the Spirit, who is the consummation of the Triune God ([link]v. 9[/link]). This corresponds with [link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link], "He who is joined to the Lord [who is the Spirit — [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]] is one spirit" — one mingled spirit.

verse.text: For those who are according to the flesh mind the [note]1[/note]things of the flesh; but those who are [note]2[/note]according to the spirit, the [note]3[/note]things of the Spirit.
verse.note: The things of the flesh include anything that is in the realm of the flesh, whether evil or good.

Not only to walk and have our activities according to the spirit, but to have our entire being according to the spirit. When we are according to the spirit, our walk also is according to the spirit. In this spirit the indwelling law of the Spirit of life, that is, the processed Triune God Himself, works within us spontaneously and frees us from the law of sin and of death.

The things of the Spirit are the things concerning Christ, which the Spirit receives and declares to us ([link]John 16:14-15[/link]). As we exercise ourselves to mind these things, eventually our whole being will be according to the spirit.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]the mind set on the flesh is [note]2[/note]death, but [note]3[/note]the mind set on the spirit is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]life and [xref]b[/xref]peace.
verse.note: Lit., the mind of the flesh. In [link]vv. 6-8[/link] the crucial item is the mind. The mind is the leading part of the soul, which is man's personality, his person. The mind thus represents the soul, that is, the person himself. In this chapter the mind is neutral, being between the regenerated mingled spirit and the fallen body, the flesh. [link]Chapters 7[/link] and [link book="Rom."]8[/link] show that the mind may have two different actions, by which it can cause us to be either in the spirit or in the flesh. If it relies on and attaches itself to the regenerated spirit, which is mingled with the Spirit of God, the mind will bring us into the spirit and into the enjoyment of the divine Spirit as the law of the Spirit of life ([link]v. 2[/link]). If the mind attaches itself to the flesh and acts independently, it will bring us into the flesh, causing us to be at enmity with God and to be unable to please Him ([link]vv. 7-8[/link]).

Life and peace result from setting our mind on the spirit. When our mind is set on the spirit, our outward actions are in agreement with our inner man and there is no discrepancy between us and God. He and we are at peace, not at enmity ([link]v. 7[/link]). The result is that we feel peaceful within.[br][br]When our mind is set on the flesh and the things of the flesh, the result is death, which causes us to feel separated from the enjoyment of God. We feel uneasy and deadened instead of peaceful and living. When we are minding the flesh and setting our mind on the things of the flesh, the sense of death should serve as a warning to us, urging us to be delivered from the flesh and to live in the spirit.

Lit., the mind of the spirit. Setting the mind on the spirit is the same as minding the things of the Spirit in [link]v. 5[/link]. [link]Verse 6[/link] and [link]vv. 7-13[/link] show that Christ today is the life of God in the divine Spirit ([link]v. 2[/link]) and also the indwelling life of God in God's people, because God's Spirit of life has become the indwelling Spirit in us, the Spirit in both aspects being Christ.

verse.text: Because the mind set on the flesh is enmity against God; for it is not subject to the law of God, for neither can it be.
And [note]1[/note]those who are [note]2[/note]in the flesh cannot please God.
verse.note: If we mind the flesh, or set our mind on the flesh, we become those who are in the flesh.
[link]Verses 8[/link] and [link]9[/link] emphasize the word [i]in,[/i] showing that the stress here is on the condition and experience more than on the source and position.

verse.text: But you are not in the flesh, but in the spirit, if indeed the [note]1[/note]Spirit of God [note]2[/note]dwells in you. Yet [note]3[/note]if anyone does not have the [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit of Christ, he is not [note]5[/note]of Him.
verse.note: This chapter unveils to us how the Triune God — the Father ([link]v. 15[/link]), the Son ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]29[/link], [link]32[/link]), and the Spirit ([link]vv. 9[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]13-14[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]26[/link]) — dispenses Himself as life ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]11[/link]) into us, the tripartite men — spirit, soul, and body — to make us His sons ([link]vv. 14-15[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]29[/link], [link]17[/link]) for the constituting of the Body of Christ ([link]12:4-5[/link]).

I.e., makes home, resides (cf. [link]Eph. 3:17[/link]). If we allow the Spirit of the Triune God to make His home in us, that is, to settle Himself in us with adequate room, then in our experience we are in the spirit and are no longer in the flesh. If we are so, the Triune God as the Spirit will be able to spread from our spirit ([link]v. 10[/link]) into our soul, represented by our mind ([link]v. 6[/link]), and eventually He will even give life to our mortal body ([link]v. 11[/link]).

This shows that our being of Christ depends on His Spirit. If there were no Spirit of Christ, or if Christ were not the Spirit, there would be no way for us to be joined to Him and to belong to Him. However, Christ is the Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]), and He is in our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]) and is one spirit with us ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]).

The Spirit of God and the Spirit of Christ are not two Spirits but one. Paul used these titles interchangeably, indicating that the indwelling Spirit of life in [link]v. 2[/link] is the all-inclusive, life-giving Spirit of the entire Triune God. God, the Spirit, and Christ — the three of the Godhead — are all mentioned in this verse. However, there are not three in us; there is only one, the triune Spirit of the Triune God ([link]John 4:24[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:11[/link]). [i]The Spirit of God[/i] implies that this Spirit is of the One who was from eternity past, who created the universe and is the origin of all things. [i]The Spirit of Christ[/i] implies that this Spirit is the embodiment and reality of Christ, the incarnated One. This Christ accomplished everything necessary to fulfill God's plan. He includes not only divinity, which He possessed from eternity, but also humanity, which He obtained through incarnation. He also includes human living, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension. This is the Spirit of Christ in resurrection, that is, Christ Himself dwelling in our spirit ([link]v. 10[/link]) to impart Himself, the embodiment of the processed Triune God, into us as resurrection life and power to deal with the death that is in our nature ([link]v. 2[/link]). Thus, we may live today in Christ's resurrection, in Christ Himself, by living in the mingled spirit.

Referring to the unchangeable source and position rather than to the changeable condition and experience. We have the Spirit of Christ according to the source, the new birth; hence, we are of Christ and belong to Him. In our present experience and spiritual condition, however, we need to be not only of Him but also in Him.

verse.text: But if [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Christ is [note]2[/note]in you, though the [note]3[/note]body is [note]4[/note]dead because of sin, the [note]5[/note]spirit is [note]6[/note]life because of [note]7[/note]righteousness.
verse.note: In this verse the Spirit is not mentioned, for here the emphasis is that Christ today is the Spirit and that the Spirit of Christ is the very Christ in us. According to the fact, it is Christ; according to experience, it is the Spirit. In our experience of Him, He is the Spirit; in our worshipping Him, calling on Him, and speaking of Him, He is Christ. We receive Him as our Savior and Redeemer, but He enters into us as the Spirit. As the Redeemer, He has the title [i]Christ;[/i] as the Indweller, He has the title [i]the Spirit.[/i] These are not two who dwell in us but one Dweller in two aspects.

"Christ...in you" is the crucial point of the book of Romans. In [link]ch. 3[/link] Christ is on the cross, shedding His blood for our redemption; in [link]ch. 4[/link] He is in resurrection; in [link]ch. 6[/link] we are in Him; now, in [link]ch. 8[/link] He is the Spirit in us.

Before we believed in the Lord, our spirit within was dead and our body without was alive. Now that we have Christ in us, though our body without is dead because of sin, our spirit within is life because of righteousness. Christ's coming into us as life exposes the death situation of our body. In our spirit is Christ the Spirit as righteousness, resulting in life; but in our flesh is Satan as sin, resulting in death.

Through the fall of man, sin, bringing death with it, entered the human body, causing it to become dead and impotent in the things of God. Although God condemned sin in the flesh ([link]v. 3[/link]), this sin has not been uprooted or eradicated from man's fallen body. Hence, our body is still dead.

The regenerated human spirit, in contrast to the fallen human body. This spirit is not the Spirit of God, for the spirit mentioned here is life only under the condition that Christ is in us. For the Spirit of God to be life, no particular condition is required. Hence, the spirit's being life because of righteousness can refer only to our human spirit, not to the Spirit of God.

Our spirit has not only been regenerated and made living; it has become life. When we believed in Christ, He as the divine Spirit of life came into our spirit and mingled Himself with it; the two spirits thereby have become one spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). Now our spirit is not merely living but is life.

In God's justification we have received righteousness, which is the Triune God Himself entering into our being, into our spirit. This righteousness results in life ([link]5:18[/link], [link]21[/link]); hence, our spirit has now become life.

verse.text: And if the [note]1[/note]Spirit of [note]2[/note]the One who raised Jesus from the dead [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]dwells in you, He who raised Christ from the dead will also [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]give life to your mortal bodies through His Spirit who [note]3[/note]indwells you.
verse.note: The objective facts revealed in [link]ch. 6[/link] concerning our death and resurrection in Christ become our subjective experience only when we are in the indwelling Spirit, who is revealed in [link]ch. 8[/link].

In this verse we have (1) the entire Triune God — "the One who raised Jesus from the dead," "Christ," and "His Spirit who indwells you"; (2) the process required for His dispensing, as implied in the words [i]Jesus[/i] (emphasizing incarnation), [i]Christ[/i] (emphasizing crucifixion and resurrection), and [i]raised[/i] (emphasizing resurrection); and (3) His dispensing of Himself into the believers, as shown by the words [i]give life to your mortal bodies,[/i] which indicate that the dispensing not only occurs at the center of our being but also reaches to the circumference, to our whole being.
See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup][/link].

This does not refer to divine healing but to the result of our allowing the Spirit of God to make His home in us and saturate our entire being with the divine life. In this way He gives His life to our mortal, dying body, not merely to heal it but also that it may be enlivened to carry out His will.

verse.text: So then, brothers, we are debtors not to the flesh to [note]1[/note]live according to the flesh;
verse.note: After we are saved, it is still possible for us to live according to the flesh by setting the mind on the flesh. But when we are in spirit and walk according to the spirit, we are freed from the flesh and are no longer obligated to it as debtors.

verse.text: For if you live according to the flesh, you must [note]1[/note]die, but if by the Spirit you [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]put to death the [note]3[/note]practices of the body, you will live.
verse.note: In this verse, to die, to put to death, and to live are spiritual matters, not physical.

We must put to death the practices of the body, but we must do it by the Spirit. On one hand, we must take the initiative to put to death the practices of the body; the Spirit does not do it for us. On the other hand, we should not attempt to deal with our body by relying on our own effort without the power of the Holy Spirit.[br][br]The putting to death here is actually our coordinating with the Spirit who indwells us. Inwardly, we must allow Him to make His home in us that He may give life to our mortal body ([link]v. 11[/link]). Outwardly, we must put to death the practices of our body that we may live. When we take the initiative to put to death the practices of our body, the Spirit comes in to apply the effectiveness of Christ's death to those practices, thus killing them.

It is not the body itself but its practices that we must put to death. The body needs to be redeemed ([link]v. 23[/link]), but its practices need to be put to death. These practices include not only sinful things but also all things practiced by our body apart from the Spirit.

verse.text: For as many as are [note]1[/note]led by the [note]2[/note]Spirit of God, these are [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]sons of God.
verse.note: The leading by the Spirit is not outward but inward, and is composed of the law of the Spirit of life ([link]v. 2[/link]), the Spirit ([link]vv. 9-13[/link]), and life ([link]vv. 6-11[/link]). This verse speaks of our being led by the Spirit rather than of the Spirit's leading us, indicating that although the Spirit is ready to lead us, we must take the initiative to be led by Him. This means that we must take Him as our life and everything and that we must put to death everything of the old creation in us. We do not need to seek after the Spirit's leading, since it is already present within us, dwelling in our regenerated spirit. If we live under this leading, we will walk and behave in a way that proves that we are God's sons.

The leading here is not merely an action of the Spirit. It is the Triune God Himself becoming the leading in our spirit. If we would care for Him as a person who indwells us, we will spontaneously be led by Him.

The central thought of the book of Romans is that God's salvation makes sinners His sons, who have His life and nature so that they can express Him, that they may become members of Christ to constitute the Body of Christ for His expression. Hence, sonship is stressed in this chapter ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]23[/link]). [i]Sons[/i] here indicates a more advanced stage of growth in the divine life than does [i]children[/i] in [link]v. 16[/link], yet not as advanced as [i]heirs[/i] in [link]v. 17[/link]. [i]Children[/i] refers to the initial stage of sonship, the stage of regeneration in the human spirit. Sons are the children of God who are in the stage of the transformation of their souls. They not only have been regenerated in their spirit and are growing in the divine life, but they also are living and walking by being led by the Spirit. Heirs are the sons of God who, through the transfiguration of their body in the stage of glorification, will be fully matured in every part of their being. Hence, they will be qualified as the legal heirs to claim the divine inheritance ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]23[/link]).

verse.text: For you have not received a spirit of slavery [i]bringing you[/i] into fear again, but you have received a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit of sonship in which we [xref]b[/xref]cry, [note]2[/note]Abba, Father!
verse.note: Our regenerated human spirit, mingled with the Spirit of the Son of God (see note [link]6[sup]3[/sup] in Gal. 4[/link]). Sonship in this spirit includes the life, the position, the living, the enjoyment, the birthright, the inheritance, and the manifestation of a son. Such an all-inclusive sonship is now in our spirit.

An Aramaic word that means [i]father.[/i] After being regenerated, we are no longer merely God's creatures; we are His children. Because we have now been born of God and are related to Him in life, it is very normal and sweet for us to call Him "Father" (see note [link]6[sup]4[/sup] in Gal. 4[/link]).

verse.text: The Spirit Himself [xref]a[/xref]witnesses [note]1[/note]with [note]2[/note]our [xref]b[/xref]spirit that [note]3[/note]we are [xref]c[/xref]children of God.
verse.note: It is not only that the Spirit witnesses and our spirit witnesses also. Rather, it is that the Spirit witnesses with our spirit. This indicates that our spirit must take the initiative to witness first; then the Spirit will witness with our spirit.

This reveals that the Spirit of God today, the all-inclusive Spirit of the Triune God, dwells in our regenerated human spirit and works in our spirit. These two spirits are one; they live together, work together, and exist together as one mingled spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). See [link]John 3:6[/link]; [link]4:24[/link]; and notes there.

This is the witnessing of the Spirit when we cry "Abba, Father" ([link]v. 15[/link]). Such a witnessing testifies to us and assures us that we are the children of God, who possess His life; it also limits us and restricts us to a living and walk that are according to this life, in keeping with our being children of God. The Spirit witnesses to our most basic and elementary relationship with God, namely, that we are His children; He does not witness that we are His sons or His heirs. Therefore, this witnessing of the Spirit begins from the time of our spiritual birth, our regeneration.

verse.text: And if children, [xref]a[/xref]heirs also; on the one hand, heirs of God; on the other, joint heirs with Christ, [note]1[/note]if indeed we [xref]b[/xref]suffer with [i]Him[/i] that we may also be [xref]c[/xref]glorified with [i]Him.[/i]
verse.note: This shows that there is a condition for us to be heirs. It is not that we are heirs simply because we are children of God. Rather, after being born as children, we must grow in life to become sons, and then we must pass through suffering that we may be glorified to become legal heirs.

verse.text: For I [note]1[/note]consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the coming [xref]a[/xref]glory to be revealed [note]2[/note]upon us.
verse.note: I.e., consider after calculating.
Lit., into, to.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note]anxious watching of the creation eagerly awaits the [note]2[/note]revelation of the sons of God.
verse.note: Lit., watching with head outstretched, with full concentration.

An unveiling or appearing of something previously covered or hidden. Although we are the sons of God, we are veiled, not yet revealed. At the Lord's second coming, when we will be glorified and our bodies will be fully redeemed, the veil will be lifted. The creation is eagerly awaiting this. This revelation will be the consummation of the process of designation that we are now passing through (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]).

verse.text: For the creation was made subject to [xref]a[/xref]vanity, not of its own will, but because of Him who subjected [i]it,[/i]
In hope that the creation itself will also be [note]1[/note]freed from the slavery of corruption into the freedom of the [xref]a[/xref]glory of the children of God.
verse.note: At present the creation is enslaved under the law of decay and corruption. Its only hope is to be freed from the slavery of corruption into the freedom of the glory of the children of God when the sons of God are revealed.

verse.text: For we know that the whole creation groans together and travails in pain together until now.

And not only [i]so,[/i] but we ourselves also, who have [note]1[/note]the firstfruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves [note]2[/note]groan in ourselves, eagerly awaiting [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]sonship, the [xref]b[/xref]redemption of our body.
verse.note: The firstfruits of the Spirit are simply the Spirit Himself as the firstfruits. The Triune God is our enjoyment; He is everything to us. There will be a harvest of this blessing at the redemption of our body; that will be the full enjoyment. Today the Spirit is the firstfruits of the coming harvest, the foretaste of our full enjoyment of God.

Although we have the divine Spirit as the firstfruits in our spirit, our body has not yet been saturated with the divine life. Our body is still the flesh, linked to the old creation, and it is still a body of sin and death that is impotent in the things of God. Hence, we groan together with the creation ([link]vv. 19[/link], [link]22[/link]) and eagerly await the glorious day when we will obtain the full sonship, the redemption and transfiguration of our body, and will be freed from the slavery of corruption.
This sonship began with the regeneration of our spirit, is continuing with the transformation of our soul, and will be consummated with the redemption of our body.

verse.text: For we were saved in hope. But a [xref]a[/xref]hope that is seen is not hope, for who hopes for what he sees?
But if we hope for what we do not see, we eagerly await [i]it[/i] through endurance.

Moreover, [note]1[/note]in like manner the Spirit also joins in to help [i]us[/i] in our [note]2[/note]weakness, for we do not know for what we should pray as is fitting, but the Spirit Himself [xref]a[/xref]intercedes for [i]us[/i] with groanings which cannot be uttered.
verse.note: [i]In like manner[/i] indicates that prior to the help of the Spirit mentioned in this verse, there was already another help of the Spirit, which must be the help rendered to us by the Spirit as the firstfruits mentioned in [link]v. 23[/link]. This is confirmed by the fact that both [link]v. 23[/link] and this verse speak of our groaning.

The weakness here is our ignorance of how we should pray. We do not know the kind of prayer God desires, and we are not clear how to pray, according to the burden we feel, for our being conformed to the image of God's Son; hence, we groan ([link]v. 23[/link]). In our groaning the Spirit groans also, interceding for us. His interceding is mainly that we may experience the transformation in life for growth into the maturity of sonship that we may be fully conformed to the image of God's Son.

verse.text: But He who searches the hearts knows what the [note]1[/note]mind of the Spirit is, because He intercedes for the saints [note]2[/note]according to God.
verse.note: This is not the mind of the Spirit that is independent of us. It is the mind of the Spirit that has been mingled with our mind ([link]v. 6[/link]) and has become a part of our heart. The Spirit not only has mingled Himself with our spirit; He has also mingled His mind with our mind.
The interceding Spirit prays for us not according to something of God but according to God Himself, that we may be conformed to the image of God's Son.

verse.text: And we know that [note]1[/note]all things [note]2[/note]work together for [note]3[/note]good to those who [note]4[/note]love God, to those who are [xref]a[/xref]called according to [i]His[/i] [note]5[/note]purpose.
verse.note: Including all persons, all matters, and all things.
God the Father answers when the Spirit intercedes for us, and He arranges our circumstances, causing all things to work together for good to us.

According to the context, the good here is not related to physical persons, matters, or things. It refers to our gaining more of Christ, to our having Him wrought into our being, that we may be transformed metabolically and may eventually be conformed to His image, the image of the Son of God ([link]v. 29[/link]), that is, that we may be brought into the full sonship.

Loving God causes us to care for His desire and to be willing to coordinate with Him. God's working needs our coordination, and our coordinating with God confirms that we are called by God according to His purpose.
Referring to the purposeful determination in God's plan. This is God's purpose to produce many brothers of His firstborn Son.

verse.text: Because those whom He [note]1[/note]foreknew, He also [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]predestinated [i]to be[/i] [note]3[/note]conformed to the [xref]b[/xref]image of His Son, that He might be the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Firstborn among [note]5[/note]many [xref]d[/xref]brothers;
verse.note: In [link]vv. 29-30[/link] all the steps of God's work are described using the past tense, indicating that in His eyes all the work has been completed. Because God is the God of eternity, there is no element of time with Him.

God has predestinated us not simply that we may be sanctified, spiritual, and victorious but that we may be fully conformed to the image of His Son. This is our destiny, determined by God in eternity past.

Conformation is the end result of transformation. It includes the changing of our inward essence and nature, and it also includes the changing of our outward form, that we may match the glorified image of Christ, the God-man. He is the prototype and we are the mass production. Both the inward and the outward changes in us, the product, are the result of the operation of the law of the Spirit of life ([link]v. 2[/link]) in our being.

Christ was the only begotten Son of God from eternity ([link]John 1:18[/link]). When He was sent by God into the world, He was still the only begotten Son of God ([link]1 John 4:9[/link]; [link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]). By His passing through death and entering into resurrection, His humanity was uplifted into His divinity. Thus, in His divinity with His humanity that passed through death and resurrection, He was born in resurrection as God's firstborn Son ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]). At the same time, all His believers were raised together with Him in His resurrection ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) and were begotten together with Him as the many sons of God. Thus they became His many brothers to constitute His Body and be God's corporate expression in Him.[br][br]As the only begotten Son of God, Christ had divinity but not humanity; He was self-existing and ever-existing, as God is. His being the firstborn Son of God, having both divinity and humanity, began with His resurrection. With His firstborn Son as the base, pattern, element, and means, God is producing many sons, and the many sons who are produced are the many believers who believe into God's firstborn Son and are joined to Him as one. They are exactly like Him in life and nature, and, like Him, they have both humanity and divinity. They are His increase and expression in order that they may express the eternal Triune God for eternity. The church today is a miniature of this expression ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]), and the New Jerusalem in eternity will be the ultimate manifestation of this expression ([link]Rev. 21:11[/link]). This book reveals that God's making sinners His sons is for this expression ([link]12:5[/link]) and points to the ultimate manifestation of this expression ([link]Eph. 3:19[/link]).

The purpose of God's foreknowledge, predestination, and calling is to prepare and produce many brothers for His firstborn Son (see note [link]17[sup]2[/sup] in John 20[/link]) that, on the one hand, they, together with God's firstborn Son, may be the many sons of God with the divine life and nature for the expression of God, and that, on the other hand, they may be the many members who constitute the Body of God's firstborn Son as the corporate expression of God in His firstborn Son, which is the fullness of God's firstborn Son, that is, the fullness of God in His firstborn Son ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]; [link]3:19[/link]).

verse.text: And those whom He predestinated, these He also called; and those whom He called, these He also [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]justified; and those whom He justified, these He also [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]glorified.
verse.note: Justification is a bridge that brings sinners, who are redeemed by Christ, from the law's condemnation ([link]3:19[/link]) into God's acceptance ([link]5:1-2[/link]). In this acceptance God works to conform them to the image of His Son until He brings them into His glory ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]).

Glorification is the step in God's complete salvation in which God will completely saturate our body of sin, which is of death and is mortal ([link]7:24[/link]; [link]8:11[/link]; [link]6:6[/link]), with the glory of His life and nature according to the principle of His regenerating our spirit through the Spirit. In this way He will transfigure our body, conforming it to the resurrected, glorious body of His Son ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]). This is the ultimate step in God's complete salvation, wherein God obtains a full expression, which will ultimately be manifested in the New Jerusalem in the coming age.

verse.text: What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who [i]can be[/i] against us?
Indeed, He who did not spare His own Son, but [xref]a[/xref]delivered Him up for us all, how shall He not also with Him freely give us [xref]b[/xref]all things?
Who shall bring a [xref]a[/xref]charge against God's chosen ones? [note]1[/note]It is God who [xref]b[/xref]justifies.
verse.note: Or, Shall God, who justifies?

verse.text: Who is he who condemns? [note]1[/note]It is Christ Jesus who [xref]a[/xref]died and, rather, who [xref]b[/xref]was raised, who is also [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]at the right hand of God, who also [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]intercedes for us.
verse.note: Or, Shall Christ Jesus, who died...for us?

This verse states that Christ today is at the right hand of God, in the heavens; [link]v. 10[/link], however, states that He is now in us, in our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). As the Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]), He is omnipresent, being both at the right hand of God and in our spirit, both in heaven and on earth.

In this verse it is Christ who intercedes for us, yet in [link]v. 26[/link] it is the Spirit who intercedes for us. These are not two Intercessors but one, the Lord Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]). He is interceding for us at two ends. At one end it is the Spirit in us, probably initiating the intercession for us; at the other end it is the Lord Christ at the right hand of God, probably completing the intercession for us, which must be mainly that we will be conformed to His image and brought into His glory.

verse.text: Who shall separate us from the [xref]a[/xref]love of Christ? Shall tribulation or anguish or persecution or famine or nakedness or peril or sword?
As it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"For Your sake we are being [xref]b[/xref]put to death all day long; we have been accounted as sheep for slaughter."
But in all these things we [note]1[/note]more than conquer through Him who loved us.
verse.note: Because of God's unchanging love for us and the fact that Christ has accomplished everything on our behalf, neither tribulation nor persecution can suppress or defeat us; rather, in all these things we more than overcome and conquer through Him who loved us.

verse.text: For I am persuaded that neither death nor life nor angels nor principalities nor things present nor things to come nor powers
Nor height nor depth nor any other creature will be able to separate us from the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verse.note: The love of God is the source of His eternal salvation. This love is in Christ and has been poured out in our hearts through the Holy Spirit ([link]5:5[/link]). Nothing can separate us from this love of God ([link]vv. 38-39[/link]). In God's salvation this love to us has become the love of Christ ([link]v. 35[/link]), which does many marvelous things for us through the grace of Christ until God's complete salvation is accomplished in us. These marvelous things provoke God's enemy to attack us with all kinds of sufferings and calamities ([link]vv. 35-36[/link]). However, because of our response to the love of God in Christ, these attacks have become benefits to us ([link]v. 28[/link]). Hence, we more than conquer in all our afflictions and calamities ([link]v. 37[/link]).[br][br]By the end of [link]ch. 8[/link] this book has covered the first half of God's salvation in Christ. This salvation has saved us to the extent that, on the one hand, we are in God's acceptance enjoying the source of this salvation, which is God's love in Christ, from which we cannot be separated by any person, matter, or thing; and, on the other hand, we are in God's life being conformed by the Lord Spirit to reach the ultimate goal of this salvation, that is, to enter into the incomparable divine glory and be glorified together with God ([link]vv. 18[/link], [link]30[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I speak the truth in Christ, I do not lie, my [note]2[/note]conscience bearing witness with me in the Holy Spirit,
verse.note: After covering the first half of God's salvation in Christ, and before going on to the second half, the section from [link]chs. 9-11[/link] is inserted to explain in detail the selection of God's chosen people, which was of God Himself.
In [link]8:16[/link] the Holy Spirit witnesses with our spirit, whereas in this verse our conscience bears witness with us in the Holy Spirit. This proves that our conscience is in our human spirit.

verse.text: That I have great grief and unceasing pain in my heart.
For I could wish that I myself were a [note]1[/note]curse, [i]separated[/i] from Christ for my brothers, my kinsmen according to the flesh,
verse.note: For Paul to wish that Israel would be saved was necessary, but to wish that he himself would be a curse and would be separated from Christ would have been extreme. Paul could wish in this way out of a desperation produced by his intense desire for Israel's salvation.

verse.text: Who are Israelites, whose are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sonship and the [xref]b[/xref]glory and the [xref]c[/xref]covenants and the [xref]d[/xref]giving of the law and the [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]service and the [xref]f[/xref]promises;
verse.note: Sonship here is the right of inheritance.
The service in the tabernacle or in the temple, instituted according to the law of Moses.

verse.text: Whose are the fathers, and out of whom, as regards what is according to flesh, is the Christ, who is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]God [xref]b[/xref]over all, [xref]c[/xref]blessed forever. Amen.
verse.note: It is clearly stated here that Christ is God, proving that although Christ was a man ([link]5:15[/link]) with flesh who came out of the tribe of Judah, a tribe of Israel, He is also God, who is over all and blessed forever. He is both man and God. He is God the Son, and He is the Triune God.

verse.text: But it is not as though the word of God has fallen away, for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]not all who are out of Israel are Israel;
verse.note: This shows God's economy in His selection. All Jews are born of Israel, but not all of them have been selected by God. Only Isaac and a part of his descendants have been selected by God and reckoned as the children of God ([link]vv. 7-8[/link]). This selection is not of man's works but of the Lord who calls and of His mercy ([link]vv. 11[/link], [link]16[/link]).

verse.text: Neither is it that because they are the seed of [xref]a[/xref]Abraham, they are all children; but, [xref]b[/xref]"In Isaac shall your seed be called,"
That is, [i]it is[/i] not the children of the flesh [i]who[/i] are the [xref]a[/xref]children of God, but the [xref]b[/xref]children of the promise are accounted as the seed.
For this is the word of promise, [xref]a[/xref]"At this time [i]next year[/i] I will come, and Sarah shall have a son."
And not only [i]so,[/i] but [xref]a[/xref]Rebecca also, having conceived by one, Isaac our father,

Though [i]the children[/i] had not yet been born nor had done anything good or bad (that the [note]1[/note]purpose of God according to [xref]a[/xref]selection might remain, not of works but of Him who [xref]b[/xref]calls),
verse.note: See note [link]28[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: It was said to her, [xref]a[/xref]"The greater shall [note]1[/note]serve the less";
verse.note: Lit., serve as a slave.

verse.text: As it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated."
What then shall we say? Is there unrighteousness with God? Absolutely not!

For to Moses He says, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"I will have [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]mercy on whomever I will have mercy, and I will have [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]compassion on whomever I will have compassion."
verse.note: This is God's sovereign authority, which allows Him to have mercy on man according to His desire.

Mercy refers mainly to an action taken in response to man's wretched condition; hence, God's showing mercy to man is outward. Compassion, however, refers mainly to an inward feeling that is expressed by groanings and tears; hence, God's having compassion on man is inward. Therefore, compassion is deeper than mercy.

verse.text: So then it is not of him who wills, nor of him who runs, but of God who shows mercy.
For the Scripture says to Pharaoh, [xref]a[/xref]"For this very thing I have raised you up, that I might show in you My power, and that My name might be proclaimed in all the earth."
So then He has mercy on whom He wills, and He hardens whom He wills.
You will say to me then, Why does He still find fault? For who withstands His will?
But rather, [xref]a[/xref]O man, who are you who answer back to God? Shall the thing molded say to him who molded it, Why did you make me thus?
Or does not the [xref]a[/xref]potter have authority over the clay to make out of the same lump one [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]vessel unto honor and another unto dishonor?
verse.note: This indicates that God chose us that we might be vessels of honor to contain Him. God created man as a vessel to contain Him, and out of the many vessels He chose us to contain Him, the God of honor, that we might be vessels of honor. Finally, He makes known His glory upon us, the vessels, that we might become vessels of His glory ([link]v. 23[/link]). All this is out of His mercy and according to His mercy; it cannot be obtained by our efforts. For this reason we must worship Him, and we must worship Him for His mercy!

verse.text: And what if God, wishing to demonstrate His [xref]a[/xref]wrath and make His power known, endured with much long-suffering vessels of wrath fitted for destruction,
In order that He might make known the [xref]a[/xref]riches of His glory upon [xref]b[/xref]vessels of [xref]c[/xref]mercy, which He had before prepared unto [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]glory,
verse.note: This is the glory in the manifestation of the coming kingdom, in which we, the revealed sons of God, will participate ([link]8:17-23[/link]).

verse.text: [i]Even[/i] us, whom He has also [xref]a[/xref]called, not only from among the Jews but also from among the Gentiles?
As He also says in Hosea, [xref]a[/xref]"I will call those who were not My people My people, and her who was not beloved beloved;
And it shall be that in the place where it was said to them, [xref]a[/xref]You are not My people, there shall they be called sons of the living God."
And Isaiah cries concerning Israel, [xref]a[/xref]"Though the number of the sons of Israel be like the sand of the sea, [i]it is[/i] the remnant [i]that[/i] shall be saved;
For the Lord will execute [i]His[/i] word upon the earth, accomplishing [i]it[/i] and cutting [i]it[/i] short."
And as Isaiah has previously said, [xref]a[/xref]"Unless the Lord of hosts had left us a seed, we would have become like [xref]b[/xref]Sodom and been made like Gomorrah."
What then shall we say? That the Gentiles who did not pursue righteousness have laid hold of righteousness, but a righteousness which is out of faith;
But [xref]a[/xref]Israel, pursuing a law of righteousness, did not attain to [i]that[/i] law.
Why? Because [i]they pursued it[/i] not [xref]a[/xref]out of faith, but as it were out of works. They stumbled at the [xref]b[/xref]stone of stumbling,
As it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Behold, I lay in Zion a stone of stumbling, a rock of offense, and he who believes on Him shall not be put to shame."
Brothers, the good pleasure of my heart and my petition to God for them is for [i]their[/i] [xref]a[/xref]salvation.
For I bear them witness that they have a zeal for God, but not according to full knowledge;
For because they were ignorant of God's righteousness and sought to [note]1[/note]establish their own righteousness, they were not subject to the [xref]a[/xref]righteousness of God.
verse.note: The Israelites seek to establish their own righteousness by trying to keep the law, and have not submitted themselves to the righteousness of God, which is Christ Himself. This is an insult to God, and it causes them to miss the way of God's salvation.

verse.text: For Christ is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]end of the law unto righteousness to everyone who believes.
verse.note: Christ came to fulfill the law ([link]Matt. 5:17[/link]) that He might terminate the law and replace it ([link]8:3-4[/link]). Thus, everyone who believes in Him receives God's righteousness, which is Christ Himself.

verse.text: For Moses writes [i]concerning[/i] the righteousness which is out of the law: [xref]a[/xref]"The man who does them shall live by them."
But the righteousness which is out of faith speaks in this way, [xref]a[/xref]"Do not say in your heart, Who will ascend into [xref]b[/xref]heaven?" that is, to [note]1[/note]bring Christ down;
verse.note: This refers to Christ's incarnation.

verse.text: Or, "Who will descend into the [note]1[/note]abyss?" that is, to [note]2[/note]bring Christ up from the dead.
verse.note: The Greek word is used in [link]Luke 8:31[/link] in reference to the dwelling place of the demons; in [link]Rev. 9:1[/link], [link]2[/link], [link]11[/link] to denote the place out of which the locusts, whose king is Apollyon (Antichrist), will come; in [link]Rev. 11:7[/link] and [link]17:8[/link] to signify the place out of which the beast, the Antichrist, will ascend; and in [link]Rev. 20:1[/link], [link]3[/link] to specify the place into which Satan will be cast and imprisoned during the millennium. The Septuagint, the Greek translation of the Old Testament, uses this word for [i]deep[/i] in [link]Gen. 1:2[/link]. Here, in this verse, it points to the place Christ visited after His death and before His resurrection, which place, according to [link]Acts 2:24[/link], [link]27[/link], is Hades; for [link]Acts 2:24[/link], [link]27[/link] reveals that Christ went into Hades after He died, and rose from that place in His resurrection. Hence, according to biblical usage, the word [i]abyss[/i] always refers to the region of death and of Satan's power of darkness, which is the lower parts of the earth ([link]Eph. 4:9[/link]), into which Christ descended after His death, which He conquered, and from which He ascended in His resurrection.
This refers to Christ's resurrection.

verse.text: But what does it say? [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart," that is, the word of the faith which we proclaim,
verse.note: Here [i]the word[/i] is used interchangeably with [i]Christ[/i] ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]), indicating that this word is Christ. Christ was incarnated by coming down from heaven and was resurrected by coming up from Hades. Thus, He has become the living Word, the Spirit ([link]Eph. 6:17[/link]), to be in our mouth and in our heart, just like the air, the breath, that can be taken into our being. He is near and He is available.
