verse.text: That if you [xref]a[/xref]confess with your [note]1[/note]mouth [xref]b[/xref]Jesus as Lord and believe in your heart that God has [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]raised Him from the dead, you will be saved;
verse.note: Christ needs our participation in Him. Since we have been made vessels to contain Him, we need to believe with our heart to receive Him, and to call on Him continually with our mouth to take Him in, thus allowing His riches to fill our empty vessel ([link]9:21-23[/link]).

Christ's being raised from the dead was invisible; hence, it requires our believing. Moreover, although Christ's death has redeemed us, it is His life in resurrection alone that can save us. Therefore, only when we believe in the great miracle that God performed in Him in raising Him from the dead can we be both redeemed and saved.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]with the heart there is believing [note]2[/note]unto righteousness, and [note]1[/note]with the mouth there is confession [note]2[/note]unto salvation.
verse.note: To believe with the heart is toward God; to confess with the mouth is toward man. To believe with the heart is to believe in Christ, who was glorified and raised by God from the dead; to confess with the mouth is to confess that Jesus, who was despised and rejected by man, is Lord. Both are conditions for our being justified and saved.
I.e., resulting in.

verse.text: For the Scripture says, [xref]a[/xref]"Everyone who believes on Him shall not be put to shame."

For there is no distinction between [xref]a[/xref]Jew and Greek, for the same Lord [i]is[/i] [xref]b[/xref][i]Lord[/i] of all [i]and[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]rich to all who [xref]d[/xref]call upon Him;
verse.note: This shows that God selects us, redeems us, justifies us, sanctifies us, conforms us, and glorifies us in Christ in order that we may enjoy His unsearchable riches in Christ ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]). The secret to this enjoyment is to call on His name.

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]"whoever [note]1[/note]calls upon the name of the Lord shall be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]saved."
verse.note: Calling on the name of the Lord is the secret not only to our salvation but also to our enjoyment of the Lord's riches. Beginning with Enosh, the third generation of mankind, and continuing all the way down to the New Testament believers, God's chosen and redeemed ones enjoyed Christ's redemption and salvation and all His riches by means of this secret (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 2[/link]).

To be saved here means to be brought into the enjoyment of the riches of the Lord. The Lord is rich to both Jews and Greeks. All who call on the Lord's name enjoy this rich Lord; as a result, they are filled with Him and express Him.

verse.text: How then shall they call upon [i]Him[/i] into whom they have not [note]1[/note]believed? And how shall they believe [i]into Him[/i] of whom they have not [note]2[/note]heard? And how shall they hear without one who proclaims [i]Him?[/i]
verse.note: One who believes into the Lord will surely call on the Lord's name. Calling on the Lord results in immediate salvation ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]13[/link]).
This implies that believing is through the word and is due to the word ([link]v. 17[/link]).

verse.text: And how shall they proclaim [i]Him[/i] unless they are sent? As it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"How beautiful are the [xref]b[/xref]feet of those who announce the news of good things!"
But not all have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]obeyed the gospel, for Isaiah says, [xref]b[/xref]"Lord, who has believed what he has heard from us?"
verse.note: To our human feeling, obeying the gospel is deeper than believing the gospel. Before we believe the gospel, we are first subdued by the Holy Spirit so that we will obey the gospel. Those who do not obey the gospel may become enemies of God's gospel ([link]11:28[/link]), enemies of God Himself.

verse.text: So faith [i]comes[/i] out of [xref]a[/xref]hearing, and hearing through the [xref]b[/xref]word of Christ.
But I say, Have they not heard? Yes surely: [xref]a[/xref]"Their voice has gone out into all the earth and their words to the ends of the inhabited earth."

But I say, Did Israel not know [i]this?[/i] First, Moses says, [xref]a[/xref]"I will [xref]b[/xref]provoke you to jealousy by [i]them who are[/i] not a nation; by a nation without understanding I will anger you."
And Isaiah is very bold and says, [xref]a[/xref]"I was found by those who did not seek Me; I became manifest to those who did not ask for Me."
But with regard to Israel he says, [xref]a[/xref]"All the day long I have stretched out My hands to a people who disobey and contradict."
I say then, Has God [note]1[/note]cast away His people? Absolutely not! For [xref]a[/xref]I also am an Israelite, out of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
verse.note: Chapters 9 and 10 may seem to indicate that God, having originally chosen Israel, has now given them up. Here, however, the apostle, using himself and Elijah as examples, proves that this is not the case.

verse.text: God has not cast away His people whom He foreknew. Or do you not know what the Scripture says in [i]the passage concerning[/i] Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel?
[xref]a[/xref]"Lord, they have killed Your prophets, they have torn down Your altars; and I am left alone, and they are seeking my [note]1[/note]life."
verse.note: Lit., soul.

verse.text: But what does the divine answer say to him? [xref]a[/xref]"I have reserved for Myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Baal."
verse.note: Baal, which in Hebrew means [i]master, possessor,[/i] was the name of a chief idol of the Phoenicians and Canaanites.

verse.text: In the same way then at the present time also there has come into being a remnant according to the [xref]a[/xref]selection of grace.
But if by [xref]a[/xref]grace, it is no longer out of works; otherwise grace is no longer grace.
What then? That which [xref]a[/xref]Israel is seeking after, this it has not obtained, but the chosen have obtained [i]it,[/i] and the rest have been [xref]b[/xref]hardened;
As it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"God gave them a spirit of deep sleep, eyes to see not and ears to hear not, until this very day."
And David says, [xref]a[/xref]"Let their table become a snare and a trap and a stumbling block and a retribution to them;
[xref]a[/xref]Let their eyes be darkened so that they cannot see; and bend their back continually."
I say then, Have they [note]1[/note]stumbled so as to fall? Absolutely not! But by their misstep salvation [i]has come[/i] to the Gentiles, to provoke them to jealousy.
verse.note: Israel stumbled on the stone of stumbling, Christ ([link]9:32[/link]), but did not fall. Rather, they only misstepped in order that God's salvation might come to the Gentiles ([link]Acts 13:46[/link]). This is God's economy in His selection.

verse.text: But if their misstep [i]has become[/i] riches for the world, and their loss, riches for the Gentiles, how much more will their fullness be!
But I am speaking to you, the Gentiles. Inasmuch therefore as I am an apostle of the Gentiles, I glorify my ministry,
If perhaps I may provoke [i]those of[/i] my flesh to jealousy and save some of them.
For if their being cast aside is the reconciliation of the world, what will their being received back be, if not life from the dead?
Now if [i]the[/i] [xref]a[/xref][i]dough[/i] offered as the [note]1[/note]firstfruits is holy, the lump is also; and if the [note]1[/note]root is holy, the branches are also.
verse.note: The three patriarchs, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, referred to in [link]v. 28[/link] as "the fathers," are the firstfruits of the dough, which were offered to God for His satisfaction. They are also the root that supports the branches of God's cultivated olive tree, Israel.

verse.text: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, being a wild olive tree, were [note]1[/note]grafted in among them and became a fellow partaker of the root of fatness of the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]olive tree,
verse.note: Grafting produces an organic union (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]). It is not the exchanging of a poor life for a better life. Rather, it is the uniting of two lives as one so that they may share one mingled life and one living. Such a mingling of life takes place when two similar yet different lives pass through death (cutting) and resurrection (growth). This depicts our union with Christ.

According to the word in [link]Matt. 2:15[/link], "Out of Egypt I called My Son," a quotation from [link]Hosea 11:1[/link], Christ and the real Israel are one entity. When the Gentile believers are grafted into Christ, they are grafted into Israel, the cultivated olive tree, to become fellow partakers of the fatness (Christ) of the root (the patriarchs — [link]v. 16[/link]), the unsearchable riches of God in Christ ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]). They and Israel have become the branches of Christ, the true vine ([link]John 15:1[/link], [link]5[/link]), and with Him the two have become the organism that expresses the Triune God.

verse.text: Do not boast against the branches; but if you boast, [i]remember that it is[/i] not you [i]who[/i] bear the root, but the root you.
You will say then, Branches were broken off so that I might be grafted in.
Rightly [i]said:[/i] they were broken off because of [xref]a[/xref]unbelief, and you stand by faith. Do not be high-minded, but fear;
For if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will He spare you.

Behold then the kindness and severity of God: on those who fell, severity; but on you, the [xref]a[/xref]kindness of God, if you continue in His kindness; otherwise you also will be [xref]b[/xref]cut off.
And they also, if they do not continue in [xref]a[/xref]unbelief, will be grafted in, for God is able [note]1[/note]to graft them in again.
verse.note: This will occur at the Lord's second coming, when all the remnant of the nation of Israel will repent and turn to believe in Him as their Messiah and be saved ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26[/link]).

verse.text: For if you were cut off from what is by nature a wild olive tree and were grafted contrary to nature into the cultivated olive tree, how much more will these who are the natural [i]branches[/i] be grafted into their own [xref]a[/xref]olive tree!

For I do not want you, brothers, to be ignorant of this mystery (lest you be wise in yourselves), that [xref]a[/xref]hardness has come upon Israel in part, until the fullness of the [note]1[/note]Gentiles comes in;
verse.note: Referring to the repentant and believing Gentiles. The completion of the fullness of the believing Gentiles is different from the fulfillment of the times of the Gentiles ([link]Luke 21:24[/link]). The latter denotes the termination of the time of Gentile power.

verse.text: And thus all Israel will be saved, as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"The Deliverer will come out of Zion; He will turn away ungodliness from Jacob.
And this is the covenant from Me with them, when I take away their sins."
According to the gospel they are enemies [note]1[/note]for your sake, but according to the [xref]a[/xref]selection they are beloved [note]1[/note]for the fathers' sake.
verse.note: This shows clearly God's economy in His selection. Israel's unbelief affects their relationship with God. Nevertheless, since the calling that issues out of God's selection is irrevocable ([link]v. 29[/link]), they are still the beloved people of God positionally.

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]gracious gifts and the [xref]b[/xref]calling of God are irrevocable.
For just as you once disobeyed God, but now have been shown [xref]a[/xref]mercy because of their disobedience,
So these also now have disobeyed, so that because of the mercy [i]shown[/i] to you they also now may be shown mercy.
For God has [xref]a[/xref]shut up all in disobedience that He might [note]1[/note]show [xref]b[/xref]mercy to all.
verse.note: Man's disobedience even fulfills God's mercy.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Oh, the [xref]a[/xref]depth of the [xref]b[/xref]riches and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]wisdom and [xref]d[/xref]knowledge of God! How [xref]e[/xref]unsearchable are His judgments and untraceable His ways!
verse.note: This is a praise to God for His riches, wisdom, and knowledge, which are beyond what man can search and trace, and which God exercised in creating all things and in arranging all things for the fulfillment of the selection of His chosen people. This praise and that in [link]16:25-27[/link], at the end of this book, are of different sources and have different goals. The former comes out of God's selection and has the accomplishing of God's selection as the goal; the latter comes out of God's mystery in the times of the ages and has the fulfillment of that mystery as the goal. Both result in the giving of glory to God.

Wisdom is deeper and higher than knowledge. Wisdom is seen in the initiation of something, whereas knowledge is seen in the practical application of the thing that was initiated by wisdom. God is the unique Initiator, as seen especially here in the matter of His selection. His wisdom in initiating His selection and His knowledge in carrying it out, as described in these chapters, deserve our highest praise!

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For who has known the mind of the Lord, or who has become His counselor?
Or who has first given to Him, and it will be repaid to him?
Because [xref]a[/xref]out from Him and [xref]b[/xref]through Him and [xref]c[/xref]to Him are all things. [xref]d[/xref]To Him be the glory forever. Amen.

[note]1[/note]I [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]exhort you therefore, brothers, through the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]compassions of God to [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]present your bodies a [note]5[/note]living [xref]d[/xref]sacrifice, holy, [xref]e[/xref]well pleasing to God, [i]which is[/i] your [note]6[/note]reasonable [note]7[/note][xref]f[/xref]service.
verse.note: After the parenthetical word that explains in detail God's selection, this book, continuing [link]ch. 8[/link], speaks concerning the latter half of God's complete salvation in Christ. In this latter half, those who enjoy the first half of God's complete salvation are members one of another as the Body of Christ ([link]v. 5[/link]). Furthermore, they have the living of the Body of Christ on the earth to express Christ in different localities (such as those enumerated in [link]ch. 16[/link]) that the Triune God may be expressed in such a living, as taught in the five chapters of the holy Word in this section, which concern the various aspects of this living. The first half of God's complete salvation, revealed in [link]chs. 1-8[/link], is the procedure by which God achieves His purpose; the second half of God's complete salvation, revealed in [link]chs. 12-16[/link], is the purpose of God's complete salvation.
Or, beg.

See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 9[/link]. In Greek the compassions referred to here are plural. God has had many kinds of compassion on us, as shown in His selecting us, calling us, saving us, and bringing us into His life that we may enjoy His riches and become His expression. Through these many compassions as the means and the motivating power, the apostle exhorted us to present our bodies to God for the fulfillment of His purpose.

For the church life, the life of the Body of Christ, to be realized, our entire being is needed. Thus, this chapter speaks concerning our body ([link]v. 1[/link]), our soul ([link]v. 2[/link]), and our spirit ([link]v. 11[/link]). Our body must be presented to God for the Body of Christ.

In [link]ch. 6[/link] the members of our body are to be presented as weapons of righteousness ([link]6:13[/link]) for warfare and service. In this chapter, however, our bodies are to be presented as a living sacrifice for the church life. This sacrifice is living because it has life through resurrection; it is not like the sacrifices in the Old Testament, which were all slain. This sacrifice is also holy because, positionally, it has been separated unto God by the blood of Christ from the world and from all persons, matters, and things that are common; and because, dispositionally, the natural life and the old creation have been sanctified and transformed by the Holy Spirit with God's life and God's holy nature for God's satisfaction. Thus, this sacrifice is well pleasing to God.[br][br]In Greek, [i]bodies[/i] here is plural and [i]sacrifice[/i] is singular. This indicates that, although many bodies are presented, they become one sacrifice, implying that, although we are many, our service in the Body of Christ should not be many individual services, separated and unrelated. All our service should constitute one whole service, and this service must be unique because it is the service of the one Body of Christ.
Or, intelligent, logical, rational, in harmony with the highest reason.

Service in worship of God. See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. Before this chapter such a service is not mentioned with reference to believers other than the apostle. This indicates that the service of the believers is an issue of the growth in life described in the foregoing chapters. It indicates further that this service must be in the Body, the church. This corresponds with the types in Exodus and Leviticus, which show that the service of the priesthood rendered to God was not established until after the Tent of Meeting was built.

verse.text: And do [note]1[/note]not be [xref]a[/xref]fashioned according to [note]2[/note]this [xref]b[/xref]age, but be [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]transformed by the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]renewing of the [xref]e[/xref]mind that you may [note]5[/note][xref]f[/xref]prove what the [note]6[/note][xref]g[/xref]will of God is, that which is good and [xref]h[/xref]well pleasing and perfect.
verse.note: This means that we should not be assimilated by the world to the extent that we who have been separated from the world unto God have the same image as this age, not caring for the transformation of the Lord Spirit in us with God's essence to conform us to the Lord's glorious image ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]), which the Spirit carries out by moving and working in us through the divine life and the divine nature.

[i]This age[/i] denotes the present, practical part of the world (see note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 1[/link]), that part which we contact and in which we live; whereas the world, the evil system of Satan (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 2[/link]), is the composition of all people, matters, and things outside of God, including religious as well as secular things, as in [link]Gal. 6:14[/link], where the world mentioned is the religious world of Paul's time. This satanic world is composed of many different ages, each having its own particular pattern, characteristics, fashions, styles, and trends. We cannot forsake the world without forsaking the present age that appears before us.

Transformation is the inward, metabolic process in which God works to spread His divine life and nature throughout every part of our being, particularly our soul, bringing Christ and His riches into our being as our new element and causing our old, natural element to be gradually discharged. As a result, we will be transformed into His image ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]), that is, conformed to the image of the firstborn Son of God as His many brothers ([link]8:29[/link]). Thus we will be suitable for the building up of His Body.

After presenting our body, we need to have our mind renewed. The renewing of the mind, which results from setting the mind on the spirit ([link]8:6[/link]), is the base for the transformation of our soul. Our mind is the leading part of our soul, and as it is renewed, our will and emotion automatically follow to be renewed also. To be renewed means that a new element is wrought into our being. This produces an inward metabolic transformation, making us suitable for the building up of the Body of Christ, which is the practice of the church life. All the virtues and the overcoming in [link]chs. 12-16[/link] also are the results of this transformation.

I.e., see and discern. Based on the presenting of our bodies and the renewing of our minds, we will see, discern, and prove by testing that the will of God is to obtain a Body for Christ to be His fullness and expression.

In this chapter the will of God is that we whom God has chosen, called, redeemed, justified, sanctified, and conformed unto glorification in the preceding eleven chapters may be members one of another to have the living of the Body of Christ ([link]vv. 3-5[/link]). The Body of Christ is the peak of God's divine revelation. The living of the Body is the issue and goal of the presenting of our bodies, the renewing of our mind, and all the life practices in the foregoing chapters.

verse.text: For I say, through the [xref]a[/xref]grace given to me, to everyone who is among you, not to [note]1[/note]think more [xref]b[/xref]highly [i]of himself[/i] than he ought to think, but to think so as to be [xref]c[/xref]sober-minded, as God has apportioned to each a [xref]d[/xref]measure of faith.
verse.note: I.e., esteem himself. If we are to have the proper church life, the first thing that must be torn down is the high esteem that we have for ourselves, that we may think so as to be sober-minded. This requires that our mind be renewed by having all the negative elements within it swallowed up by the life of Christ. Then we will esteem ourselves according to the faith that God has apportioned to us, that is, according to the measure of God's element that has been transfused into us.

verse.text: For just as in [xref]a[/xref]one body we have [xref]b[/xref]many members, and all the members do not have the [xref]c[/xref]same [note]1[/note]function,
verse.note: Function is for service in the Body of Christ ([link]v. 1[/link]). In order to function, we must have life, the divine life for the divine expression.

verse.text: So we who are many are one Body [note]1[/note]in Christ, and individually [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]members one of another.
verse.note: We are one Body in Christ, having an organic union with Him. This union makes us one in life with Him and with all the other members of His Body. The Body is not an organization or a society but is altogether an organism produced by the union in life that we have with Christ.

The purpose of God's salvation is to have Christ reproduced in millions of saints that they may become the members of His Body, not separate and complete individual units but parts of a living, functioning, coordinated, corporate whole. Although these parts have different functions, they are not detached from one another. Rather, they are "individually members one of another." Each member is organically joined to all the others, and each needs the function of all the others. All the members must be coordinated together to practice the Body life that is revealed in this chapter.

verse.text: And having [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gifts that differ according to the [xref]b[/xref]grace given to us, whether [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]prophecy, [i]let us prophesy[/i] according to the [xref]d[/xref]proportion of faith;
verse.note: The gifts are received according to the grace given to us and are a result of our experience of the grace of Christ. This grace is God in Christ as the divine element coming into our being to be our life for our enjoyment. When this grace comes into us, it brings with it the element of certain spiritual skills and abilities, which, accompanying our growth in life, develop into the gifts in life that we may function in the Body of Christ to serve God. The gifts in life here are different from the gifts mentioned in [link]Eph. 4:8[/link], which refer to the gifted persons given by Christ in His ascension to His Body for its building up. The gifts in life here are also different from the miraculous gifts mentioned in [link]1 Cor. 12[/link] and [link book="1 Cor."]14[/link]. The gifts in life are developed by the growth in life and by the transformation in life mentioned in [link]v. 2[/link], out of the inward, initial gifts mentioned in [link]1 Cor. 1:7[/link].

To prophesy is to speak for God and to speak forth God under His direct revelation. Prediction may be included in prophecy, but it is not the main aspect of the prophecy mentioned here. Prophesying brings in God's revelation for the building up of the church, the Body of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 14:4b[/link]). These three — prophecy, teaching ([link]v. 7[/link]), and exhortation ([link]v. 8[/link]) — are related and coordinate with one another. The one who prophesies speaks what he has received as a direct revelation from God. The one who teaches instructs others, not based on direct revelation but based on what the prophets have spoken. He who exhorts does so according to both the direct speaking under God's revelation and the teaching that is according to this revelation. These three kinds of speaking are for the building up of the Body. They minister the life supply to the saints that they may grow together by God's word.

verse.text: Or [note]1[/note]service, [i]let us be faithful[/i] in that service; or he who [xref]a[/xref]teaches, in that teaching;
verse.note: The service of the deacons and deaconesses in the local churches. See [link]16:1[/link], [link]1 Tim. 3:8-13[/link], and [link]Phil. 1:1[/link].

verse.text: Or he who [xref]a[/xref]exhorts, in that exhortation; he who [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]gives, in simplicity; he who [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]leads, in diligence; he who [note]3[/note]shows [xref]d[/xref]mercy, in cheerfulness.
verse.note: Denoting those who give to supply the needy ones in the church and to take care of the church's practical needs.
Referring to the leading brothers in the church. In taking the lead the first quality needed is diligence.
This refers to those who show mercy by sympathizing and rendering help. The showing of mercy is not a natural generosity but a quality formed by transformation.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Let [xref]a[/xref]love be without hypocrisy. Abhor what is evil; [xref]b[/xref]cling to what is good.
verse.note: [link]Verses 9-21[/link] and [link]ch. 13[/link] show the normal Christian life that is the necessary base for the practice of the church life and that matches the church life. This life is described in five aspects: (1) toward others ([link]vv. 9-10[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]15-16[/link]); (2) toward God ([link]v. 11[/link]); (3) toward ourselves ([link]v. 12[/link]); (4) toward the persecutor and enemy ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]17-21[/link]); and (5) in general, before all men ([link]v. 17[/link]). A life that is complete and proper in these five aspects is a life of surpassing quality with an excellent issue.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Love one another warmly in brotherly love; take the lead in showing honor one to another.
Do not be slothful in zeal, [i]but[/i] be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]burning in spirit, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]serving the Lord.
verse.note: A presented body, a transformed soul, and a burning spirit — all three are indispensable to a proper church life. After we have presented our body for the church life, it is very easy for us to fall into the opinions of our mind in our soul, which results in our being damaged in the church life; therefore, our soul, and particularly the mind of our soul, needs to be transformed. However, once our mind is transformed, we may easily fall into a negative and dormant state. At that time we must be burning in spirit that we may be stirred up and encouraged to go on in the church life in a positive way.
Lit., serving as a slave. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Rejoice in hope; [xref]a[/xref]endure in tribulation; [xref]b[/xref]persevere in prayer.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Contribute to the needs of the saints; pursue [xref]b[/xref]hospitality.
verse.note: Lit., Have fellowship with. This is to care willingly for the needs of the saints according to our ability. The apostle termed this kind of material care "fellowship," because in the sharing of material things the grace of the Lord's life flows among the members of the Body of Christ and is infused into them.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bless those who persecute you; bless and do not curse.
verse.note: As Christians, we are under a blessing. Thus, we should not curse anyone but only bless. The Lord blessed us when we were His enemies ([link]5:10[/link]). In the same way, we should bless our enemies and persecutors.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Rejoice with those who rejoice; weep with those who weep.
verse.note: To live a normal Christian life for the church life, we need a proper emotion that can rejoice or weep with others. Such an emotion is not a part of our natural life; it is the issue of life through transformation.

verse.text: Be of the [xref]a[/xref]same mind toward one another, not [xref]b[/xref]setting your mind on the high things but going along with the [note]1[/note]lowly; do not be [xref]c[/xref]wise in yourselves.
verse.note: Or, lowly things.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Repay no one evil for evil; [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]take forethought for things honorable in the sight of all men.
verse.note: Since we are living not only before God but also before men, we need to take forethought for things honorable in the sight of all men.

verse.text: If possible, as far as it depends on you, live in [xref]a[/xref]peace with all men.
Do not [note]1[/note]avenge yourselves, beloved, but give place to the wrath [i]of God,[/i] for it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Vengeance is Mine, I will repay, says the Lord."
verse.note: God is sovereign. We should not avenge ourselves in any way but should leave the whole situation in the sovereign hand of the Lord, giving Him the ground to do whatever He likes.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]But "if your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him a drink; for in doing this you will heap coals of fire upon his head."
Do not be conquered by evil, but conquer evil with good.

Let every [note]1[/note]person be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]subject to the authorities over [i]him,[/i] for [xref]b[/xref]there is no authority except [note]3[/note]from God, and those which exist are [note]4[/note]ordained by God.
verse.note: Lit., soul.

The transformation mentioned in [link]12:2[/link] also governs the Christian life taught in this chapter. Man's natural character is rebellious, but a transformed character is submissive. Subjection to authority requires transformation, which results from the growth in life.

Lit., by. After man's fall, God authorized man to act as His deputy authority in ruling over man ([link]Gen. 9:6[/link]). To be subject to the authorities is to recognize God's authority and to respect His government over man. Paul's word here implies that he recognized even those officials appointed by Caesar as rulers ordained by God to be God's deputy authorities.

God ordains the authorities over man in order to maintain peace and security in human society so that He may have the time and the opportunity to preach the gospel, to save sinners, and to build the church for the spread of His kingdom.

verse.text: So then he who resists the authority opposes God's ordination, and those who oppose will receive [note]1[/note]judgment to themselves.
verse.note: Or, punishment, condemnation.

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]rulers are not a terror to the good work, but to the evil. Do you want to have no fear of the authority? Do what is good, and you will have praise from him;

For he is a [note]1[/note]servant of God to you for good. But if you do what is evil, fear; he does not bear the sword in vain; for he is a [note]1[/note]servant of God, an avenger for wrath to him who practices evil.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]deacon[/i] in [link]16:1[/link] (there rendered [i]deaconess[/i]) and [link]1 Tim. 3:8[/link].

verse.text: Therefore it is necessary to be subject, not only because of wrath but also because of conscience.
For because of this you also pay taxes; for they are God's [note]1[/note]officers, attending constantly to this very thing.
verse.note: Lit., public servants.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Render to all the things due: tax to whom tax [i]is due,[/i] custom to whom custom [i]is due,[/i] fear to whom fear [i]is due,[/i] honor to whom honor [i]is due.[/i]
Owe nothing to anyone except to [xref]a[/xref]love one another; for he who [note]1[/note]loves the other has [xref]b[/xref]fulfilled the law.
verse.note: Love is not merely an outward behavior but is the expression of the inward life. In order to love people and thus spontaneously fulfill the law, we need the transformation in life and the life supply. We need God's life and God's nature of love to transform us and supply us in life, so that in love we may live out this God, who is love, and express His love.

verse.text: For, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not commit adultery, you shall not murder, you shall not steal, you shall not covet," and if there is any other commandment, it is summed up in this word, namely, [xref]b[/xref]"You shall love your neighbor as yourself."
[xref]a[/xref]Love does not work evil to his neighbor; therefore love is the [xref]b[/xref]fulfillment of the law.
And this, knowing the [xref]a[/xref]time, that it is already the hour for you to be [xref]b[/xref]raised from sleep; for now is our [note]1[/note]salvation [xref]c[/xref]nearer than when we believed.
verse.note: Referring to the final step of salvation, the redemption of our body, the full sonship revealed in [link]8:19[/link], [link]21[/link], and 23.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]night is far advanced, and the [xref]a[/xref]day has drawn near. Let us therefore cast off the [xref]b[/xref]works of darkness, and let us put on the [xref]c[/xref]weapons of light.
verse.note: The present age is the nighttime. When the Lord Jesus returns, day will dawn. The next age, the kingdom age, will be the daytime.

verse.text: Let us walk becomingly as in the [xref]a[/xref]day; not in [xref]b[/xref]reveling and [xref]c[/xref]drunkenness, not in fornication and licentiousness, not in [xref]d[/xref]strife and [xref]e[/xref]jealousy.
But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no [note]2[/note]provision for the [xref]b[/xref]flesh to [i]fulfill its[/i] lusts.
verse.note: Although we have been baptized into Christ and are already in Christ ([link]6:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]), we must still put Him on. To put on Christ is to live by Christ ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]) and to live out Christ ([link]Phil. 1:21[/link]), thus magnifying Christ ([link]Phil. 1:20[/link]). Putting on Christ is the same as putting on the weapons of light ([link]v. 12[/link]), indicating that Christ is the weapons of light for the warfare between the Spirit and the lusts. The warfare here is the same as the conflict between the Spirit and the lusts of the flesh ([link]Gal. 5:17[/link]). However, it is different from our wrestling against the devil and his evil forces ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]) and from the warfare between the law of sin and the law of good in us ([link]7:23[/link]).

Or, arrangement. This word has the same root as the Greek word for [i]take forethought[/i] in [link]12:17[/link]. [i]To take forethought[/i] includes the meaning [i]to provide.[/i] To make no provision for the flesh is to not take any forethought for the flesh or provide the flesh with anything that will support it and make it convenient for it to fulfill its lusts.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Now him who is [xref]a[/xref]weak in faith [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]receive, [i]but[/i] not for the purpose of passing judgment on [i]his[/i] [note]3[/note]considerations.
verse.note: This chapter can be considered a supplement to the constitution of the church life. In setting forth every article, the author's heart was tolerant, his attitude was broad, and his view was noble. In order to practice the church life that he instituted in [link]ch. 12[/link], we must strictly observe the supplement set forth in this chapter. Many saints who love the Lord and seek to live the church life have failed because they were either negligent or mistaken in this matter.

To practice the Body life revealed in [link]ch. 12[/link], we must learn the practical lessons of receiving the believers, as revealed particularly in [link]14:1-15:13[/link], that the church life may be all-inclusive, able to include all kinds of genuine Christians. Such receiving requires the transformation mentioned in [link]ch. 12[/link]; if we remain natural, we will be unable to receive those whose views are different from ours in doctrine or in practice.

I.e., doctrinal considerations. Except in the matters of idol worship ([link]1 John 5:21[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 8:4-7[/link]), fornication, rapaciousness, reviling, and other such gross sins ([link]1 Cor. 5:9-11[/link]; [link]6:9-10[/link]), division ([link]16:17[/link]; [link]Titus 3:10[/link]), and the denial of the incarnation of Christ ([link]2 John 7-11[/link]), we must learn not to pass judgments on the doctrinal views of others. As long as one is a genuine Christian and has the fundamental faith of the New Testament, we should not exclude him, even though he may differ from us with respect to doctrine; rather, we should receive him in the same one Lord.

verse.text: One believes that he may eat all things, but he who is weak [xref]a[/xref]eats vegetables.
He who eats, let him [note]1[/note]not despise him who does not eat; and he who does not eat, let him [note]1[/note]not judge him who eats, for [note]2[/note]God has received him.
verse.note: Concerning the receiving of the believers, Paul used eating ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]) and the keeping of days ([link]vv. 5-6[/link]) as examples. God's receiving has nothing to do with what we eat or with our keeping of certain days. These are minor, secondary matters that have nothing to do with our salvation and basic faith. Therefore, we should not despise or judge others in these things.

The basis on which we receive the believers is that God has received them. God receives people according to His Son. When a person receives God's Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, as his Savior, God receives that person immediately and ushers him into the enjoyment of the Triune God and of all He has prepared and accomplished in Christ for us. We should receive people in the same way and should not be more narrow than God. Regardless of how much they differ from us in doctrinal concepts or religious practices, we must receive them. When we receive people according to God and not according to doctrine or practice, we demonstrate and maintain the oneness of the Body of Christ.

verse.text: Who are you who judge another's household servant? To his own master he stands or falls; and he will be made to stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.
One judges one [xref]a[/xref]day above another; another judges every day [i]alike.[/i] Let each be fully [xref]b[/xref]persuaded in his own mind.

He who regards that day, regards [i]it[/i] to the Lord; and he who eats, [xref]a[/xref]eats to the Lord, for he gives [xref]b[/xref]thanks to God; and he who does not eat, does not eat to the Lord, and he gives thanks to God.
For none of us [xref]a[/xref]lives to himself, and none dies to himself;
For whether we live, we [xref]a[/xref]live to the Lord, and whether we die, we die to the Lord. Therefore whether we live or we die, we are the [xref]b[/xref]Lord's.
For Christ [xref]a[/xref]died and lived [i]again[/i] for this, that He might be [xref]b[/xref]Lord both of the dead and of the living.
But you, why do you judge your brother? Or you, why do you despise your brother? For we will all stand before the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]judgment seat of God,
verse.note: The judgment at the judgment seat of God is different from the eternal judgment of God mentioned in [link]2:2[/link], [link]3[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]16[/link], and [link]3:8[/link], which will be carried out mainly at the great white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). The eternal judgment at the great white throne will be (1) after the millennium, (2) to judge all the dead unbelievers, and (3) for eternal punishment in the lake of fire. Since this judgment will be executed upon all the condemned sinners, it is mentioned in this book in the section on condemnation. However, the judgment at the judgment seat of God, or the judgment seat of Christ, will be (1) before the millennium, immediately after Christ's coming back, (2) to judge all the resurrected and raptured believers, and (3) for reward or punishment in the millennial kingdom. This judgment will take account of the believers' life and work after they were saved. Since this judgment is very much related to the transformation of the believers, it is mentioned here in this section on transformation.

verse.text: For it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"As I live, says the Lord, every knee shall bow to Me, and every tongue shall openly confess to God."
So then each one of us will [xref]a[/xref]give an account concerning himself to God.
Therefore let us [xref]a[/xref]judge one another no longer, but rather judge this: [xref]b[/xref]not to put a stumbling block or cause of falling before your brother.

I know and am persuaded in the Lord Jesus that there is [xref]a[/xref]nothing [note]1[/note]unclean of itself, except to him who considers something to be [note]1[/note]unclean; to that man it is [note]1[/note]unclean.
verse.note: Lit., common.

verse.text: For if because of food your brother is [note]1[/note]wounded, you no longer [xref]a[/xref]walk according to love. Do not [xref]b[/xref]destroy by your food that man for whom Christ died.
verse.note: Or, grieved.

verse.text: Therefore do not let your [xref]a[/xref]good be slandered;
For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God is not eating and drinking, but [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness and [xref]c[/xref]peace and [xref]d[/xref]joy in the Holy Spirit.
verse.note: This verse is a strong proof that the church in the church age is the kingdom of God, because the context here deals with the church life in the present age. The church is a matter of grace and life, whereas the kingdom is a matter of exercise and discipline.

The kingdom of God is the sphere in which God exercises His authority so that He may express His glory for the fulfillment of His purpose. In such a kingdom, what matters is not eating and drinking but righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit. Righteousness denotes that which is right and proper. Those who live in the kingdom of God should be right and proper toward others, toward things, and toward God; with them there should be nothing erroneous, improper, crooked, slanted, or biased. This requires that they be strict in dealing with themselves. Peace is the fruit of righteousness ([link]Heb. 12:11[/link] and note). It characterizes the relationship that those who live in the kingdom of God should have with others and with God. If we are righteous, right, and proper toward others, toward things, and toward God, we will have a peaceful relationship with others and with God. Thus, we will have joy in the Holy Spirit and, in particular, before God. In this way we will be filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit ([link]Acts 13:52[/link]) and will live out righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit, which are the reality of the kingdom of God.[br][br]According to the context of this chapter, this verse was written for our receiving of the believers. If we receive the believers according to the apostle's instruction in this chapter, we will be right and proper toward those whom we receive and will have peace with them; thus, we will have joy in the Holy Spirit, proving that we are living in the reality of God's kingdom and are under God's rule. Otherwise, we will not be right or proper toward those whom we do not receive and will not have peace with them; thus, we will not have joy in the Holy Spirit before God, proving that we are not subject to God's authority in the kingdom of God.

verse.text: For he who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]serves Christ in this is well pleasing to God and approved by men.
verse.note: Lit., serves as a slave. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. To live in the kingdom of God in the way of righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit is to serve Christ as a slave. This is well pleasing to God and approved by men, and it preserves the oneness of the church for the practical Body life.

verse.text: So then let us [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pursue the things of peace and the things for [xref]b[/xref]building up one another.
verse.note: For the proper church life we must pursue the things of peace, the things that keep the oneness of the Body, and we must pursue also the things that build up one another, the things that minister life to our fellow members for mutual building up.

verse.text: Do not [xref]a[/xref]break down the [note]1[/note]work of God for the sake of food. [xref]b[/xref]All things indeed are clean, but it is evil for a man to eat while [xref]c[/xref]stumbling [i]others.[/i]
verse.note: In all saved persons there is a measure of God's work. If we cause any one of the believers to stumble because of our doctrinal concepts, we break down, destroy, God's work of grace in him.

verse.text: It is good [xref]a[/xref]not to eat meat nor drink wine nor [i]to do anything[/i] by which your brother stumbles.
The faith which you have, have to yourself before God. Blessed is he who does not judge himself in what he approves;
But he who [xref]a[/xref]doubts is condemned if he eats, because it is not out of faith; for all that is not out of faith is sin.
But we who are strong ought to bear the weaknesses of those who are [xref]a[/xref]weak and not to please ourselves.
Let each of us please his neighbor with a view to what is good for [xref]a[/xref]building up.
For Christ also did not please Himself, but as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"The reproaches of those who reproached You fell upon Me."

For the things that were [xref]a[/xref]written previously were written for our instruction, in order that through endurance and through the [note]1[/note]encouragement of the Scriptures we might have [xref]b[/xref]hope.
verse.note: Or, comfort. So also in [link]v. 5[/link].

verse.text: Now the [xref]a[/xref]God of endurance and encouragement grant you to be of the [xref]b[/xref]same mind toward one another according to [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Christ Jesus,
verse.note: The preceding verse mentions the Scriptures and the instructions contained in them. However, in the concluding word in this verse, God sets up Christ Jesus as the standard for the church life that we may do everything in the church life according to Him, not taking any doctrine or knowledge as the standard. This will issue in the one accord mentioned in [link]v. 6[/link].

verse.text: That [note]1[/note]with [xref]a[/xref]one accord you may with [xref]b[/xref]one mouth [xref]c[/xref]glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]with the same mind, will, and purpose.[/i] This is to be one in our whole being and results in our being one in our outward speaking. Whenever we are in one accord, we speak the same thing; we speak with one mouth. This oneness is the reverse of Babel, where the division among mankind caused their language to become confused and divided into many different speakings ([link]Gen. 11:7[/link], [link]9[/link]). The only way to be with one accord and one mouth is to allow Christ the room to be everything in our heart and in our mouth that God may be glorified.

verse.text: Therefore [xref]a[/xref]receive one another, as [note]1[/note]Christ also received you to the glory of God.
verse.note: [link chapter="14"]Verse 3[/link] of [link]ch. 14[/link] says that we should receive people according to God's receiving, but here we are told that we should receive people according to Christ's receiving. Christ's receiving is God's receiving. What Christ has received, God has received. Those whom God and Christ have received we must receive, regardless of how they differ from us in doctrine or practice. This will be to the glory of God.

verse.text: For I say that Christ has become a [note]1[/note]servant of the circumcision for the sake of God's [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]truthfulness, to confirm the [xref]b[/xref]promises [i]given[/i] to the fathers,
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]deacon[/i] in [link]16:1[/link] (there rendered [i]deaconess[/i]) and [link]1 Tim. 3:8[/link]. In [link]vv. 8-9[/link] Christ is shown to be the servant of both the circumcision (the Jews) and the nations (the Gentiles). For the Jews, Christ is a servant for the sake of God's truthfulness, to fulfill and confirm all the promises God gave to their fathers. For the Gentiles, Christ is a servant so that the Gentiles may glorify God for His mercy.
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. Christ has become a servant of the circumcision to confirm the promises God gave to the fathers. This is to prove God's truthfulness.

verse.text: And that the Gentiles should glorify God for [i]His[/i] [xref]a[/xref]mercy, as it is written, [xref]b[/xref]"Therefore I will [note]1[/note]extol You among the Gentiles, and I will sing praise to Your name."
verse.note: Or, confess.

verse.text: And again he says, [xref]a[/xref]"Rejoice, Gentiles, with His people."
And again, [xref]a[/xref]"Praise the Lord, all you Gentiles, and let all the peoples speak praise to Him."
And again, Isaiah says, [xref]a[/xref]"There shall be the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]root of Jesse, even He who rises to rule the Gentiles; [xref]c[/xref]on Him will the Gentiles hope."
verse.note: Although Christ is the root of Jesse (David's father, signifying the Jewish people), He will also be the ruler of the Gentiles. The apostle quoted this word and the word in [link]vv. 9-11[/link] to prove that Christ brings together the Gentiles and the Jews. Since Christ is such an all-embracing Lord ([link]Acts 10:36[/link]), bringing together the Jews and the Gentiles, we must receive all the different believers according to Him.

verse.text: Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and [xref]a[/xref]peace in believing, that you may abound in [xref]b[/xref]hope in the [xref]c[/xref]power of the Holy Spirit.
But I myself also am persuaded concerning you, my brothers, that you yourselves also are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, able also to admonish one another.
But I have written the more boldly to you on some points so as to remind you [i]of them[/i] again because of the [xref]a[/xref]grace given to me by God

That I might be a [note]1[/note]minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, a [note]2[/note]laboring [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]priest of the gospel of God, in order that the [xref]b[/xref]offering of the Gentiles might be acceptable, having been [xref]c[/xref]sanctified in the Holy Spirit.
verse.note: Lit., public servant; as in [link]13:6[/link].
In Greek, from the same root as [i]energizing.[/i]

Paul's being a priest of the gospel of God to minister Christ to the Gentiles was a priestly service to God, and the Gentiles whom he gained through his gospel preaching were an offering presented to God. By this priestly service many Gentiles, who were unclean and defiled, were sanctified in the Holy Spirit and became such an offering, acceptable to God. They were set apart from things common and were saturated with God's nature and element, and were thus sanctified both positionally and dispositionally (see note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]). Such a sanctification is in the Holy Spirit. This means that, based on Christ's redemption, the Holy Spirit renews, transforms, and separates unto holiness those who have been regenerated by believing into Christ.

verse.text: I have therefore my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]boasting in Christ Jesus [xref]b[/xref]in the things pertaining to God.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: For I will not dare to speak anything of the things which [xref]a[/xref]Christ has not accomplished through me for the [xref]b[/xref]obedience of the Gentiles, by word and by work,

In the power of [xref]a[/xref]signs and wonders, in the [xref]b[/xref]power of the Spirit of God; so that [xref]c[/xref]from Jerusalem and round about to [note]1[/note]Illyricum, I have [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]fully preached the gospel of Christ,
verse.note: A region in southeast Europe adjacent to Macedonia. This shows Paul's widespread preaching of the gospel. He desired to travel even farther, all the way to Spain ([link]v. 24[/link]).
Lit., fulfilled.

verse.text: But [i]have done[/i] so aspiring to announce the gospel not where Christ has been named, so that I would not build upon [xref]a[/xref]another's foundation;
But as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"They will see, they to whom nothing concerning Him was announced; and those who have not heard will understand."
For this reason also I have been [xref]a[/xref]hindered these many times from coming to you.
But now I no longer have place in these regions and have had a desire since many years ago to [xref]a[/xref]come to you

Whenever I may go to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spain, for I hope to see you in passing and be [xref]b[/xref]sent forward there by you, if first I am [xref]c[/xref]filled, [i]at least[/i] in part, by your [i]company.[/i]
verse.note: At that time Paul probably considered Spain the uttermost part of the earth, as mentioned in [link]Acts 1:8[/link].

verse.text: But now I am [xref]a[/xref]going to Jerusalem, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]ministering to the saints.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]serving as a deacon.[/i]

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]Macedonia and [xref]b[/xref]Achaia have been pleased to make some [note]1[/note]contribution for the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.
verse.note: Lit., fellowship. The Greek word denotes participation and fellowship. The same word is translated [i]fellowship[/i] in [link]Phil. 1:5[/link] and [i]sharing[/i] in [link]Heb. 13:16[/link], and is from the same root as [i]contribute[/i] in [link]12:13[/link] of this book. The fellowship of love, the fellowship in love between the Gentile and the Jewish saints, developed out of the ministering of Christ to the Gentiles and the offering of the Gentiles as a sacrifice to God. Paul went to the Gentiles with Christ; now he was returning to the Jews with the fellowship of the Gentile saints in material things. This fellowship of love was the practical result of Paul's ministry.

verse.text: For they were pleased [i]to do it,[/i] and their debtors they are. For if the Gentiles have shared in their [xref]a[/xref]spiritual things, they ought also to [note]1[/note]do service to them in material things.
verse.note: The Greek word denotes the service performed by priests and Levites in the temple. It is the same word as for [i]ministering[/i] in [link]Heb. 10:11[/link]. In [link]v. 16[/link] Paul's thought was that he was a priest. Here he might have had the thought that the Gentiles were serving as Levites.

verse.text: When therefore I have finished this and have sealed to them this fruit, I will go on by way of you to [xref]a[/xref]Spain.
And I know that when I come to you, I will [xref]a[/xref]come in the [note]1[/note]fullness of the blessing of Christ.
verse.note: Paul went to the Gentiles with Christ, returned to the Jewish brothers with material possessions, and expected to visit Rome in the fullness of the blessing of Christ to minister the riches of Christ to the people there. This shows us the proper church life. Through the apostle, the church life was being filled with Christ, filled with love in the fellowship of material possessions, and filled with the mutual participation in the blessing of Christ's fullness.

verse.text: Now I [xref]a[/xref]exhort you, brothers, through our Lord Jesus Christ and through the [xref]b[/xref]love of the Spirit, to [xref]c[/xref]strive together with me in your prayers to God on my behalf,
That I may be delivered from those who are disobedient in Judea, and [i]that[/i] my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]service for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,
verse.note: The Greek word denotes the service of a deacon. In [link]v. 25[/link] and in this verse Paul might have had the thought that he was serving as a deacon.

verse.text: So that coming to you in joy through the [xref]a[/xref]will of God, I may [xref]b[/xref]refresh myself and rest with you.
Now the [xref]a[/xref]God of peace be with you all. Amen.
I [note]1[/note]commend to you Phoebe our sister, who is a [xref]a[/xref]deaconess of the [note]2[/note]church which is in [xref]b[/xref]Cenchrea,
verse.note: As the conclusion of this book, this chapter consists entirely of recommendations and greetings. It speaks not only of the concern among the saints but also of the fellowship among the churches ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]4-5[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]23[/link]), showing some of the conditions that should exist in the local churches as the fourth station revealed in this book (see note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link], par. 2) and as the conclusion of the revelation in this book. This strengthens the content and significance of this chapter, which not only contains recommendations and greetings but, even more, presents a display of the local churches.

The term [i]church[/i] is not used in this book until [link]16:1[/link]. In this chapter the church and the churches are mentioned five times ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]4-5[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]23[/link]). This is a strong indication that many matters covered in [link]chs. 1-15[/link] concerning God's complete salvation are for the producing and building up of the church. These matters include the Triune God Himself ([link]8:31[/link]), as the Father ([link]1:7[/link]; [link]8:15[/link]), as the Son ([link]1:4[/link]; [link]8:3[/link]) (the Son being the Lord — [link]1:4[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]10:12[/link]; [link]14:9[/link]; being Jesus — [link]3:26[/link]; [link]4:24[/link]; being Christ — [link]5:6[/link]; [link]6:4[/link]; [link]8:34[/link]; [link]6:3[/link]; [link]8:10[/link]; [link]13:14[/link]; being the man — [link]5:15[/link]; and being the root of Jesse — [link]15:12[/link]), and as the Spirit ([link]5:5[/link]; [link]8:16[/link], [link]26[/link]) (the Spirit being the firstfruits — [link]8:23[/link]); His mercy ([link]9:23[/link]; [link]11:32[/link]), His compassion ([link]9:15[/link]; [link]12:1[/link]), His love ([link]5:5[/link]; [link]8:35[/link], [link]39[/link]), His kindness ([link]2:4[/link]; [link]11:22[/link]), His grace ([link]5:2[/link], [link]15[/link]), His free gifts ([link]5:15-16[/link]; [link]11:29[/link]), His gifts ([link]12:6[/link]), His righteousness ([link]1:17[/link]; [link]3:21[/link]), His Spirit of holiness ([link]1:4[/link]), His faithfulness ([link]3:3[/link]), His peace ([link]15:33[/link]; [link]16:20[/link]), His hope ([link]15:13[/link]), His joy ([link]15:13[/link]), His endurance ([link]15:5[/link]), His encouragement ([link]15:5[/link]), His riches ([link]10:12[/link]; [link]11:33[/link]), His wisdom ([link]11:33[/link]), His knowledge ([link]11:33[/link]), His power ([link]1:16[/link]), His authority ([link]9:21[/link]), His life ([link]5:21[/link]), His law of life ([link]8:2[/link]), His sonship ([link]8:15[/link]), His glory ([link]5:2[/link]; [link]9:23[/link]), and His kingdom ([link]14:17[/link]); His foreknowing ([link]8:29[/link]), His selection ([link]9:11[/link]; [link]11:5[/link]), His predestination ([link]8:29[/link]), His preparation ([link]9:23[/link]), His reserving ([link]11:4-5[/link]), His calling ([link]8:30[/link]; [link]11:29[/link]), His grafting ([link]11:17[/link]), His redemption ([link]3:24[/link]), His propitiation ([link]3:25[/link]), His salvation ([link]1:16[/link]), His justification ([link]3:26[/link], [link]30[/link]), His reconciliation ([link]5:10-11[/link]), His freedom ([link]8:2[/link]), His sanctification ([link]6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]), His transformation ([link]12:2[/link]), His renewing ([link]12:2[/link]), His conformation ([link]8:29[/link]), His redemption of our body ([link]8:23[/link]), and His glorification ([link]8:30[/link]); His receiving ([link]14:3[/link]; [link]15:7[/link]), His indwelling ([link]8:11[/link]), His life giving ([link]8:11[/link]), His leading ([link]8:14[/link]), His witnessing ([link]8:16[/link]), His helping ([link]8:26[/link]), His interceding within us ([link]8:26[/link]), His interceding in the heavens ([link]8:34[/link]), His giving all things to us ([link]8:32[/link]), and His causing all things to work for us ([link]8:28[/link]); plus His incarnation ([link]1:3[/link]; [link]10:6[/link]), His crucifixion ([link]5:8[/link]; [link]6:6[/link]), His blood ([link]3:25[/link]), His ending of the law ([link]10:4[/link]), His resurrection ([link]4:25[/link]; [link]10:7[/link]), and His ascension ([link]8:34[/link]). All have been made available, and most of these have been applied to the producing and building up of the church for the fulfillment of God's purpose according to His will ([link]12:2[/link]).[br][br]Four stations are revealed in this book: the matters covered in [link]chs. 1-4[/link] bring us in [link]ch. 4[/link] to the first station, the station of justification; [link]chs. 5-8[/link] lead us in [link]ch. 8[/link] to the second station, the station of sanctification; [link]chs. 9-12[/link] lead us in [link]ch. 12[/link] to the third station, the station of the Body of Christ; and [link]chs. 13-16[/link] take us in [link]ch. 16[/link] to the fourth station, the station of the churches expressed in different localities, the station of the practical living of the Body of Christ in different localities. The churches are the ultimate consummation of the complete salvation of the gospel of God revealed in this book, which was written not in the way of doctrine but in the way of practicality. In the first station we are regenerated and saved, in the second station we are sanctified, in the third station we are renewed and transformed, and in the fourth station, in the practical church life, Satan is crushed under our feet and we are able to fully enjoy the Lord's grace and God's peace ([link]v. 20[/link]).

verse.text: That you [xref]a[/xref]receive her in the Lord in a manner [note]1[/note]worthy of the saints and assist her in whatever matter she may have need of you; for she herself has also been the [note]2[/note]patroness of many, of myself as well.
verse.note: I.e., worthy of her status as a saint. [link chapter="1"]Verse 7[/link] of [link]ch. 1[/link] says that the saints are called by God and separated from all things other than God to be a special people sanctified unto God, and as such they are noble and not common. Therefore, the apostle asked the saints in Rome to receive Phoebe as a noble saint, to receive her in a manner worthy of her noble status.

Or, protectress. It is a word of dignity, denoting one who helps, sustains, and supplies. It indicates the high esteem with which Phoebe was regarded because of her service in the church life in Cenchrea.

verse.text: Greet [xref]a[/xref]Prisca and [xref]a[/xref]Aquila, my [xref]b[/xref]fellow workers in Christ Jesus,
Who [note]1[/note]risked their own necks for my [note]2[/note]life, to whom not only I give thanks, but also all the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]churches of the Gentiles;
verse.note: Prisca and Aquila were absolute for the local churches. Their only interest was the church, and they were willing to risk their necks, to be martyred, for the apostles.
Lit., soul.

The Body of Christ as the universal church is unique ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]; [link]4:3[/link]). When this universal church appears in many localities on earth, it becomes the many churches. Therefore, this verse refers to the churches. The churches exist in various localities that all the saints may live the church life and have the practice of the church in the locality where they are.

verse.text: And [i]greet[/i] the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]church, which is in their [note]2[/note]house. Greet Epaenetus, my beloved, who is the firstfruits of Asia unto Christ.
verse.note: The church in Prisca and Aquila's house must have been the church in Rome. When they were living in Ephesus ([link]Acts 18:18-19[/link]), the church in Ephesus was in their house ([link]1 Cor. 16:19[/link]). Wherever they were, they were willing to bear the burden of the practice of the church by opening their home.
Showing that the early saints met primarily in their houses. Such a practice corresponds with [link]Acts 2:46[/link] (see note 3 there) and [link book="Acts"]5:42[/link].

verse.text: Greet Mary, one who has labored much for you.
Greet Andronicus and Junia, my [xref]a[/xref]kinsmen and my [xref]b[/xref]fellow prisoners, who are of note among the apostles, who also were in Christ before me.
Greet Ampliatus, my beloved in the Lord.
Greet Urbanus, our [xref]a[/xref]fellow worker in Christ, and Stachys, my beloved.
Greet Apelles, [note]1[/note]approved in Christ. Greet [note]2[/note]those of the [i]household of[/i] Aristobulus.
verse.note: Lit., approved by testing.

According to the structure and the tone of these expressions, those of the households of Aristobulus and Narcissus could not be members of the families of the two men; they were most likely the slaves of the two men, respectively. According to the ancient custom, slaves were considered the property of their buyers. It is unlikely that the two masters, Aristobulus and Narcissus, were believers, because they were not greeted here. At that time a number of those who had been sold as slaves and had lost their freedom believed in Christ and became saints, but the masters who bought them were not yet believers.

verse.text: Greet Herodion, my [xref]a[/xref]kinsman. Greet [note]1[/note]those of the [i]household of[/i] Narcissus who are in the Lord.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa, who labor in the Lord. Greet Persis, the beloved [i]sister,[/i] one who has labored much in the Lord.
Greet [xref]a[/xref]Rufus, [xref]b[/xref]chosen in the Lord, and his mother as well as [note]1[/note]mine.
verse.note: Rufus was a brother in Rome, and his mother also was in Rome. Paul's referring to her as his own mother was a sign of respect and intimacy.

verse.text: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers with them.
Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints with them.
Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]churches of Christ greet you.
verse.note: The churches are not the personal possession or private work of anyone. They are the churches of Christ.

verse.text: Now I [xref]a[/xref]exhort you, brothers, to [xref]b[/xref]mark those who make [xref]c[/xref]divisions and causes of [note]1[/note]stumbling contrary to the [xref]d[/xref]teaching which you have learned, and [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]turn away from them.
verse.note: Referring to being stumbled and leaving the church life. This must be the result of different opinions and teachings.

In [link]ch. 14[/link] Paul was liberal and gracious regarding the receiving of those who differ in doctrine or practice. Here, however, he is unyielding and resolute in saying that we must turn away from those who are dissenting, who make divisions, and who make causes of stumbling. The purpose in both cases is the preserving of the oneness of the Body of Christ that we may have the normal church life.

verse.text: For such men do not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]serve our Lord Christ, but their own [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]stomach, and through [xref]c[/xref]smooth words and flattering speech deceive the hearts of the [note]3[/note]simple.
verse.note: Lit., serve as slaves.
The Greek word is a derivative of the word meaning [i]hollow.[/i] It refers to the stomach or to the entire abdominal cavity.
Or, unsuspecting, innocent.

verse.text: For [i]the report of[/i] your [xref]a[/xref]obedience has reached to all; therefore I rejoice over you, but I want you to be wise as to what is good and guileless as to what is evil.
Now the [xref]a[/xref]God of peace will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]crush Satan [xref]c[/xref]under your feet shortly. The [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
verse.note: Here God promises that He will crush Satan under the feet of those who live the church life, showing that the crushing of Satan is related to the church life. Dealing with Satan is a Body matter, not an individual matter. It is only when we have a proper local church as the practical expression of the Body that Satan is crushed under our feet.
The church life enables us not only to crush Satan under our feet and to experience the God of peace but also to enjoy the rich grace of the Lord.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Timothy, my [xref]b[/xref]fellow worker, greets you, as well as Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my [xref]c[/xref]kinsmen.
I, Tertius, who write this epistle, greet you in the Lord.
[xref]a[/xref]Gaius, my host and [i]host[/i] of the whole church, greets you. [xref]b[/xref]Erastus, the city treasurer, greets you, and Quartus the brother.
[i]See note 24[note]1[/note].[/i]
verse.note: Some ancient MSS add [link]v. 24[/link], The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now to Him who is able to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]establish you according to [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]my gospel, that is, the [xref]d[/xref]proclamation of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]mystery, which has been kept in silence in the [note]4[/note]times of the ages
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]7[/sup] in 1 Pet. 5[/link]. In [link]ch. 16[/link] our need is no longer to be saved or to be sanctified but to be established. Since everything has been accomplished, we need only to be established. This establishing is according to the pure and full gospel of God, that is, the proclaiming and ministering of the all-inclusive Christ, and according to the revelation of the mystery, which has been kept in silence in the times of the ages. Only the pure gospel, the living Christ, and God's revealed mystery can establish us and keep us in oneness for the church life.
I.e., the full gospel, including the teaching concerning Christ and the church and consummating in the local churches, as fully disclosed in this book. See note [link]1[sup]9[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

The mystery of God, which has been kept in silence in the times of the ages, is mainly of two aspects: the mystery of God, which is Christ ([link]Col. 2:2[/link]), who is in the believers ([link]Col. 1:26-27[/link]) as their life and their everything that they may become the members of His Body; and the mystery of Christ, which is the church as His Body ([link]Eph. 3:4-6[/link]) to express His fullness ([link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]). Therefore, Christ and the church are the great mystery ([link]Eph. 5:32[/link]).
Referring to the time since the beginning of the world.

verse.text: But has now been manifested, and through the [xref]a[/xref]prophetic writings, according to the command of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]eternal God, has been made known to all the Gentiles for the [xref]c[/xref]obedience of faith;
verse.note: In [link]chs. 15[/link] and [link book="Rom."]16[/link] God is called "the God of endurance and encouragement" ([link]15:5[/link]), "the God of hope" ([link]15:13[/link]), "the God of peace" ([link]v. 20[/link]), "the eternal God" ([link]v. 26[/link]), and "the only wise God" ([link]v. 27[/link]). Our God is rich in all these aspects, and the gospel in this book is the gospel of such a rich God. This gospel consummates in the practical church life.

verse.text: To the [xref]a[/xref]only [note]1[/note]wise God through Jesus Christ, to Him be the [xref]b[/xref]glory forever and ever. Amen.
verse.note: See note [link]33[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]. In its conclusion this book, which gives a general discussion concerning the Christian life and the church life, gives glory to the wise God. This unveils that all the matters discussed in this book, such as how God selects us, how He saves us from sin and death, how He redeems us and justifies us, how He makes us, sinners who were dead through and through, His divine sons, how He transfers us out of Adam into Christ, how He sanctifies and transforms us in Christ, how He makes us the members of Christ for the constituting of the Body of Christ, and how He causes us to be the local churches appearing in different localities as the expressions of the Body of Christ on the earth in this age — all these matters are planned, managed, and accomplished by God's wisdom, in order that He, the unlimitedly rich Triune God, may be glorified, that is, that His incomparable glory may be completely and fully expressed through us who have been perfected eternally by Him and who have become His Body and have been joined to Him as one. The focus of God's wisdom is the working of His Divine Trinity into the three parts — spirit, soul, and body — of our redeemed being that in His redemption, sanctification, and transformation we may have a full union in the divine life with Him, that His desire for the mingling of divinity and humanity, the joining of humanity to divinity, may be fulfilled for eternity. This truly is worthy of our appreciation and worship! How blessed and how glorious it is that we can participate in this! This is worthy of our unceasing singing and praise for eternity! Both our Christian life and our church life should have this as our center and goal. May God bless in this way everyone who has been chosen and perfected by Him.[br][br]Through God's divine dispensing in us and His divine union with us, we can experience and enjoy the saving in Christ's life in God's full salvation (see note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]), as conveyed to us in this book, in the following aspects:[br][br](1) By the abundance of grace (God Himself) and of the gift of righteousness (Christ Himself) which we received, we are able to reign in Christ's divine life ([link]5:17[/link]) over sin, death, the old man, the flesh, Satan, the world, and all persons, matters, and things that do not submit to God.[br][br](2) God's holy nature sanctifies our worldly disposition ([link]6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]). God sanctifies us dispositionally out of His divine life and unto His divine life that we may enjoy more of His divine life.[br][br](3) The indwelling law of the Spirit of life, that is, the automatic and spontaneous working of the Triune God as life in us, frees us from the law of sin and of death, the slavery and bondage of sin ([link]8:2[/link], [link]11[/link]). The operation of this law comes out of God's divine life, and it also causes the increase of the divine life in us.[br][br](4) The Divine Trinity's divine dispensing in our spirit, soul, and body causes these three parts to be saturated with the processed divine life ([link]8:5-11[/link]), with the result that our entire being is completely united with the processed Triune God and mingled with Him as one.[br][br](5) The renewing of our mind by the Spirit results in the transformation of our soul, which saves us from being conformed to the modern style of the world ([link]12:2[/link]) and issues in all the virtues and the overcoming, mentioned in [link]chs. 12-16[/link], as our daily life, a life of the highest standard, and as our church life, a life that is all-overcoming.[br][br](6) By the renewing of our mind and the transformation of our soul, we become members one of another with all believers in the Body of Christ and are built up together as the Body of Christ and thereby have the service of the Body ([link]12:1[/link], [link]3-8[/link]). This is the crystallization of our experience of the saving in Christ's life.[br][br](7) Based on the revelation and teaching in [link]chs. 14-16[/link] of this book, we live the life of the local church in different localities as the appearance of the Body of Christ, the universal church, in different localities.[br][br](8) By becoming the built-up church, a church against which the gates of Hades cannot prevail, in different localities, we afford God the opportunity to crush Satan under our feet that we may enjoy Christ as our rich grace and the God of peace as our surpassing peace ([link]16:20[/link]).[br][br](9) In our experience of the various aspects of the saving in the divine life, as mentioned above, we are being conformed to the image of the firstborn Son of God ([link]8:28-29[/link]) through the "all things" arranged under God's sovereignty, so that we have His divine attributes and His human virtues and thereby express the glory and beauty of Him, the God-man.[br][br](10) In the process of our experience of the saving in the divine life, the splendor of the divine life gradually saturates us until it saturates our body, issuing in the redemption of our body ([link]8:23[/link]), that our spirit, soul, and body may all enter into the glory of God ([link]8:30[/link], [link]17[/link]). This glorification is the peak attained in us by the saving in the divine life, and it is the climax of God's full salvation.
